issue: Hello everyone, I found this StackOverflow question where somebody says that this usage of NativeWebRequest is not thread-safe. Now I'm a bit worried because I want to do the same thing. Is that user correct? [<-LINK->]solution:
solution: It is thread-safe. Spring controllers are indeed singletons (by default) that are called concurrently by multiple threads. But the request which is injected in the controller is not actually an HTTP request. BTW, at the time the controller is constructed, the server hasn't received any request yet. The request is in fact a proxy, which, whenever one of its methods is called, finds the current request being processed (by the current thread), and delegates to that request.

solution: That question is too vague to get any concrete answer. but if you need one, no..

issue: The rest template calls happen right next to each other. I only set the mock server to expect 1 of them. Both of the resttemplate calls happen on a different thread, but they finish before the `.verify()` is called. shouldn't the verify fail? From debugging through verify it seems that it doesn't actually verify the number of calls, it just verifies the expectations I provided. `AbstractRequestExpectationManager#verify` should check the count of actual calls. ``` @Override public void verify() {  if (getExpectations().isEmpty()) {   return;  }  int count = 0;  for (RequestExpectation expectation : getExpectations()) {   if (!expectation.isSatisfied()) {    count++;   }  }  if (count > 0) {   String message = "Further request(s) expected leaving " + count + " unsatisfied expectation(s).\n";   throw new AssertionError(message + getRequestDetails());  } }``` all it does is check that the single expectation I passed ```requestTo(allOf(                startsWith("http://localhost:9008/workforceUsers"),                endsWith("/authorities/CAN_BE_ASSIGNED_AS_LOAN_OFFICER/userAssociations")))```succeeded, and not that the `once()` was true.

org/springframework/boot/context/properties/source/ConfigurationPropertySource```Any clues on what could be wrong? 
solution: It's in `spring-web`, which is a dependency of `spring-boot-starter-web`. Here you've overridden `spring-web` with a very old Spring Framework version. That's the source of your problem.

issue: Another issue with the webflux setup is: `org.springframework.web.reactive.function.UnsupportedMediaTypeException: Content type 'application/json' not supported`. Do I have to include any extra starters to have support for JSON serialization? 
solution: 

issue: `validator.validate(Object, Errors)`? In a Spring Boot app the validator is autowirable, I think So you just use its API That's `org.springframework.validation.Validator` Actually the question was unclear wasn't it? You said "webflux" and then linked to a SO question on functional handlers (not the same thing) 
solution: 

issue: And, just to be clear, that only applies to the functional model. If you’re using WebFlux with `@Controller`, `@RequestMapping` etc, I believe validation can be used as it is with Spring MVC 
solution: Yes. 

issue: @orestis_f_twitter a bit hard to say with this sample, but I guess you should compose `thenMany` with a `map` operator that uses the object mapper. Right now your composition chain does not return a `Flux< BaseSocketMessage >` but most probably a `Mono<Void>` that signals when the work is done. Also, `doOnNext` is a side-effect operator and you're not supposed to call I/O operations in it. @orestis_f_twitter also, please stop cross-posting here and in the reactor channel. 
solution: 

issue: @bclozel thanks! Why cross-posting is bad? There is a (mostly) different set of people on those two channels and my question involved Spring and Reactor Anyway I will refrain from doing it again

issue: @james-mcgivern I get what you say about Entity as service issue, but I think this is up to the developer to choose and avoid such pitfall but there is plenty of times where this can be just fine. When developing a single tool that does just few things I tend to run with it. If I know that I will need integrations and this is going to be part of a bigger infrastructure I will avoid it like the plague! So, like you said not much spring-boot related issue in my opinion. Agreed

issue: I have multi module Gradle project with the following:```configure(allprojects) { project ->    apply plugin: "java"    apply plugin: "io.spring.dependency-management"    sourceCompatibility = 1.8    repositories {        mavenCentral()    }    dependencies {        compile("org.apache.commons:commons-lang3:${dependencyManagement.importedProperties['commons-lang3.version']}")    }}```However the `commons-lang3` version resolves to `null`... should I include something else?Note that some sub modules apply the boot plugin as well, but not all of them.

issue: we've tightened the rules for configuration properties (see here: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/wiki/Spring-Boot-2.0-Migration-Guide#externalized-configuration). Maybe your `application.properties` or `application.yml` has a property related to jackson that's not mapped well with the new constraints?

issue: Hi QQ, is there a way to configure the thread pools for netty/reactor in spring webflux? I would like to reduce the request queuing [![image.png](https://files.gitter.im/spring-projects/spring-boot/A3H3/thumb/image.png)](https://files.gitter.im/spring-projects/spring-boot/A3H3/image.png) is the green area on this chart, reported by New Relic 
solution: 

issue: @FcoJavierSainz Reactor Netty uses an event loop with a small number of threads that’s tied to the number of processor cores. Configuring the number of threads is far more unusual than it was with a blocking servlet container. If you do want to configure it, you can use a `NettyServerCustomizer` bean 
solution: 

issue: Thanks. I see the problem. It’s the `MeterRegistryPostProcessor` that’s triggering it. A `MeterRegistry` is created before the `WebServer` has been created. The creation of the `MeterRegistry` triggers the initialization of all `MeterBinder` beans so that they can be bound to the registry. 
solution:

issue: @snicoll in springboot 2.0.0.RC2  i use Binder to solve properties, found can not change `${spring.application.name}` to real value [![image.png](https://files.gitter.im/spring-projects/spring-boot/tdMj/thumb/image.png)](https://files.gitter.im/spring-projects/spring-boot/tdMj/image.png) [![image.png](https://files.gitter.im/spring-projects/spring-boot/daLw/thumb/image.png)](https://files.gitter.im/spring-projects/spring-boot/daLw/image.png) but other's property is ok in bootstrap.yml config file```spring:  application:    name: sample-elasticJob``` this code in springboot 1.5.x is ok but in 2.0 i change to use binder , but found invalid in value like `${spring.application.name}` spel 
solution: ```new Binder(ConfigurationPropertySources.from(environment.getPropertySources()))          .bind(targetName, Bindable.of(clazz))          .orElseThrow(              () -> new FatalBeanException("Could not bind DataSourceSettings properties"));```.

When starting the application from within Eclipse, everything works fine. solution: 

issue: Some libraries don't work in the fat jar because of this kind of thing. Generally they broke something to do with context class loaders or URL resolution. Maybe use `requiresUnpack`? 
solution: AFAIK, the service loader mechanism just uses the ClassLoader to find `META-INF/services`. As long as the right ClassLoader is used, it should just work. For example, Log4j2 uses `META-INF/services` and it works fine in a fat jar.. 

issue: Yeah that doesn't make any sense

solution: 

issue: The former will match any Actuator Endpoint, the latter will match anything at all The explanation of what the former does is in the method’s javadoc, btw It’s in an actuator package and part of the actuator auto-configuration module so we hoped that would be enough. We prefer not to make class names too long if we can avoid it

issue: depends on what feature you’re looking for (I know you’ve disabled restart) There is a `PropertySource` that’s added to the `Environment`, you could look for that 
solution: 

issue: so this is an edge-case that cannot be (easily) solved? 
solution: I can’t really advise on the solution without knowing exactly why the problem’s occurring. It’s usually due to one of two things:1. The code that’s creating the instance is using reflection and the wrong class loader to do so2. The application is configured such that its code is split across the two class loadersThe second one can be fixed via configuration: https://docs.spring.io/spring-boot/docs/current/reference/htmlsingle/#using-boot-devtools-customizing-classload. 

issue: I’m happy to take a look if you can share some code that reproduces the problem

solution: 

issue: Spring Boot 2 migration nearly done.  Woohoo!  As far as I can tell, the last issue is that Swagger 2 no longer works.  I had @EnableWebMvc that added two resource handlers ("swagger-ui.html" and "/webjars/**") and with that it works, but WebMvcConfigurationAdapter is deprecated.  Any idea on how to get Swagger to work without WebMvcConfigurationAdapter? 
solution: 

issue: Just implement `WebMvcConfigurer` directly. Default methods in Java 8 mean that the adapter class is redundant. Also, you probably don’t want `@EnableWebMvc` in a Boot app as it’ll switch off all of the auto-configuraton of Spring MVC With Boot’s auto-configuration, a `WebMvcConfigurer` bean will be picked up without `@EnableWebMvc`. That might be all you intended to use it for, but you’re also switching off all of Boot’s MVC auto-configuration by using it 
solution: Note that `/webjars/**` is handled for you by the MVC auto-configuration so if you remove `@EnableWebMvc` you can focus on the Swagger-specific stuff (just `swagger-ui.html`, probably).. 

issue: I only added @EnableWebMVc to get swagger to work.  That's all I use it for 
solution: 

issue: ok thanks

issue: I see that it throws `SqlExceptionHelper: Driver@f4a08543 returned null for URL` exception, but it doesn't stop the boot process 
solution: 

issue: "@Where" annotation? use it with caution it will not applied on joins if entity A has relationship to entity B and B is deleted findAll() on A will make those "deleted" B reachable however if you try find that B by id - you will get nothing it creates a lot of confusion, so think about it in prior I have no silver bullet for this but I would recommend avoid "@Where" only straightforward "isdeleted = false" in query builders/repositories or if use where apply it to every relationship also @OneToMany(fetch=FetchType.LAZY, mappedBy="parent")@Where(clause = "isdeleted = false")public List<Child> children; it is easy to forgot to put where to every relation 
solution: 

issue: `user.isdeleted IS FALSE` is it correct syntax for your db? another issue is that where uses plain sql, not jpql so it is not portable :) 
solution: 

issue: depends if you need to inject it somewhere as part of the contextx lifecycle or not

issue: If you want the request URL to be logged for any filter that throws an exception, it’s the container that’ll need to do the logging Alternatively, you could declare your own `Filter` ordered with highest precedence that catches `Throwable`, logs whatever you need, and then rethrows

issue: @wilkinsona I’ll try with the deployment structure file, as I do not have that in my app. Well, the culprit seems to be whether the WAR is compiled with JDK 1.8 or 9. If compiled with 9, Spring does not start in WildFly 12; if with 1.8, it does. In WildFly 11 it starts with both. Somehow, WildFly 12 does not provide Spring the `WebApplicationInitializers` if compiled with Java 9. https://issues.jboss.org/browse/WFLY-9961

issue: @wilkinsona  trying to limit the size so it won't go pass 1MB because my backend has a hard limit for processing data payload ideally would like to set it to  1048576 ( 1 MB), noted your reference, I was under the impression that  setting server.tomcat.max-http-post-size would revise the underlying embedded  tomcat container maxSize, but that does not seem to be the case. My request is a json payload which contains a based64 encoded attribute, if that matters. I will try giving this a shot: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/33232849/increase-http-post-maxpostsize-in-spring-boot ```java// Set maxPostSize of embedded tomcat server to 10 megabytes (default is 2 MB, not large enough to support file uploads > 1.5 MB)@BeanEmbeddedServletContainerCustomizer containerCustomizer() throws Exception {    return (ConfigurableEmbeddedServletContainer container) -> {        if (container instanceof TomcatEmbeddedServletContainerFactory) {            TomcatEmbeddedServletContainerFactory tomcat = (TomcatEmbeddedServletContainerFactory) container;            tomcat.addConnectorCustomizers(                (connector) -> {                    connector.setMaxPostSize(10000000); // 10 MB                }            );        }    };}``` no dice, requests still go thru without capping or erroring out at configured maxPostSize.

solution: 

issue: So is there a way to get at what I'm trying to do? 
solution: Hmm, I guess you could make some assumptions based on your endpoint's URL. Your endpoint will be called with something like `http://example.com/actuator/your-endpoint-id`. If you chop `/your-endpoint-id` off the URL and then pass that to the links resolver I think you’ll get the right answer. 

issue: I don’t think you actually need the value of the `BEST_MATCHING_PATTERN_ATTRIBUTE` The request URL from the `HttpServletRequest` is the right thing to use in the Servlet case. That’s what’s used in the mapping that produces all the endpoint links On the WebFlux side, you want the `ServerWebExchange` so that you can get the request and retrieve its URI. I’m not sure how to do that as `RequestContextHolder` is thread-bound and Servlet-specific.

solution: 

issue: okey now i can t go back i should do it a spring boot inside osgi container can u help me trying to do it with steps or links & thank you for the response i get it now   @wilkinsona 
solution: No, not really. I wouldn’t advise anyone to use OSGi and Spring. I don’t think that OSGi brings enough value to Spring applications to justify the added complexity. At this point, if you must use OSGI, then I don’t think you should try to use Spring (or any of the JVM ecosystem that’s typically used with Spring)..

issue: Yeah, maybe. @snicoll How would I use the cache in my code? 
solution: I already told you. (though I can’t be definitive since I am not sure I understand what you’re doing). 

issue: what is not the case? 
solution: There's no `CacheManager` bean auto configured here …. 

issue: But shouldn't ```        <dependency>            <groupId>org.springframework.boot</groupId>            <artifactId>spring-boot-starter-cache</artifactId>        </dependency>``` be enough? 
solution: Speficically>The @EnableCaching annotation triggers a post processor that inspects every Spring bean for the presence of caching annotations on public methods. If such an >annotation is found, a proxy is automatically created to intercept the method call and handle the caching behavior accordingly.>>The annotations that are managed by this post processor are Cacheable, CachePut and CacheEvict. You can refer to the javadocs and the documentation for more >details.>>Spring Boot automatically configures a suitable CacheManager to serve as a provider for the relevant cache. See the Spring Boot documentation for more details.>>Our sample does not use a specific caching library so our cache store is the simple fallback that uses ConcurrentHashMap. The caching abstraction supports a wide >range of cache library and is fully compliant with JSR-107 (JCache).?. 

issue: Sorry but I can’t continue this discussion at the moment. I don’t understand what you’re doing. If you follow the guide then you must have a cachemanager bean (if you don’t, you’re not using caching at all) 
solution: I still don’t know why it doesn’t work for you and the guide is all that you need to get a CacheManager bean in your project so compare the guide with your own setup. If that doesn’t work, share a sample that I can run myself, it will be more effective.

issue: Thanks @bclozel I see the fix was done to replace my-project (kebab-case) to myProject (camel case) for the prefix? Is that the expectation. I assume with 2.0 we can't have camel case in prefix. *All prefixes must be in kebab-case format (lower-case, hyphen separated), acme.myProject or acme.my_project are invalid - you must use acme.my-project here.* (Reference the migration guide https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/wiki/Spring-Boot-2.0-Migration-Guide#relaxed-binding ) @bclozel filed https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/issues/12782

issue: @JagmohanSharma actuator endpoints are already producing metrics data, just like any other web endpoint in your app and I don't understand what you mean by `add metrics for any particular actuator endpoint and off for others` you want to enable disable metrics on a per endpoint basis? or add different tags depending on the the endpoint? `ResponseEntityExceptionHandler` doesn't exist in webflux. But `@ControllerAdvice` and `@ExceptionHandler` do work.In Spring Boot, you get even more support with the error handling (see the reference documentation for Spring Boot)

solution: 

issue: reactive programming paradigm uses non-blocking async model…so, threads keep on reused for different tasks... good thing is, in project reactor, the team addressed this issue and came up with a solution (http://projectreactor.io/docs/core/release/reference/#context) which works…but it certainly requires code change and spring-cloud-sleuth’s 2.x version uses a hybrid approach (reactor context + ThreadLocal) to propagate the trace ids …i am rt now evaluating this for my app

solution: alright, let me share my beans:```    @Bean    public RestTemplate restTemplate(HttpComponentsClientHttpRequestFactory httpComponentsClientHttpRequestFactory){        return new RestTemplateBuilder()                .requestFactory(httpComponentsClientHttpRequestFactory)                .build();    }    @Bean    public HttpComponentsClientHttpRequestFactory httpComponentsClientHttpRequestFactory() {        HttpComponentsClientHttpRequestFactory httpComponentsClientHttpRequestFactory = new HttpComponentsClientHttpRequestFactory();        httpComponentsClientHttpRequestFactory.setReadTimeout(1000);        httpComponentsClientHttpRequestFactory.setConnectTimeout(1000);        return httpComponentsClientHttpRequestFactory;    }    @Bean    public OAuth2RestTemplate oAuth2RestTemplate(HttpComponentsClientHttpRequestFactory httpComponentsClientHttpRequestFactory) {        OAuth2RestTemplate oAuth2RestTemplate = new OAuth2RestTemplate(resource());        oAuth2RestTemplate.setRequestFactory(httpComponentsClientHttpRequestFactory);        return oAuth2RestTemplate;    }```.

issue: @ramkifx as per the exception you are missing the connectionUrlhere is a sample yaml connfiguration``` yamlspring:    datasource:        driver-class-name: org.h2.Driver        username: sa        password:         url: jdbc:h2:mem:db_name#        type: com.zaxxer.hikari.HikariDataSource    jpa:        properties:            hibernate:                dialect: org.hibernate.dialect.H2Dialect```uncomment spring.datasource.type line if you are not using springboot 2.0.0+ as it uses hikari by default,and don't forget the dialect if you are using hibernate

solution: 

issue: No `WebClient` doesn’t have support for a mock server yet in framework so we can’t offer that feature I am afraid I don’t and I’d expect this to be described in the framework ref doc if that’s not the case, I’d open an issue in the issue tracker at https://jira.spring.io/projects/SPR 
solution: 

issue: @joshfix You’re a bit stuck then. I’d open an issue against the open source library and ask them to subclass `WebMvcConfigurerAdapter` if possible. Even without Boot in the picture, subclassing `WebMvcConfigurationSupport` in a library is going to cause problems No. MVC auto-configuration is switched off by either using `@EnableWebMvc` or sub-classing `WebMvcConfigurationSupport`. A `WebMvcConfigurerAdapter` allows you to add to the auto-configured MVC support 
solution: 

issue: ok, will that not prevent the mvc autoconfiguration? ok!  thank you very much!

issue: @pmihalcin The only difference between the two is Docker. Neither is embedding everything. The Docker approach has the advantage of you not having to have Erlang installed You could take it a step further with Testcontainers. That’ll integrate starting and stopping the Docker container into your tests. It works pretty well in my experience; we use it in Boot’s CI (although not specifically with Rabbit).

issue: @sauravsingh29 I think you could refactor most of it inside a `ExchangeFilterFunction` that you can configure at the `WebClient.Builder` level. Instead of throwing exceptions, you should probably `return Mono.error(new MyException());`. Throwing should work anyway, but using Mono.error is more idiomatic and easier to read when you're composing a pipeline.

issue: A bean with an `@EventListener` method is adapted into an `ApplicationListener` 
solution: No, it doesn’t have to be `@Component` for `@EventListener` methods to be picked up, it just has to be a bean.. If you want to some form of dynamic registration (I think that’s what you’re asking for), I think you’ll have to implement `ApplicationListener` directly rather than using `@EventListener`.

issue: Unless `EcmDbSvc` is an unusually named Data JPA repository, it’s not going to be found by component scanning:> By default, it configures an in-memory embedded database, scans for @Entity classes, and configures Spring Data JPA repositories. I want users to post some Messages. ```    @GetMapping("/contact")    public String getContact(Model model) {        Message message = new Message();        message.setCreationDate(Instant.now());        message.setStatus(MessageStatus.CREATED);        model.addAttribute("message", message);        return "contact";    }    @PostMapping("/contact")    public String postMessage(@Valid Message message, BindingResult bindingResult, Model model) {        if (!bindingResult.hasErrors()) {            log.info("Sending message by {} - Message : {}", message.getCustomer().getEmail(), message.getContent());            messageService.save(message);        }        return "contact";    }```The Message entity has a `@NotNull` constraint for `creationDate` and `status` attributes. issue: Hello, what does MessageSourceAutoConfiguration does that Hibernate Validator cannot resolve messages from provided message source? 1. Added `@EnableWebMvc` annotation 2. solution: 

issue: @wilkinsona @dsyer Finally found the source of the problem with my thin boot app.  What I had earlier referred to as a class loader problem turned out to be a case of the SSL stack of the VM being initialized too soon when the Thin launcher was resolving dependencies using https to our internal repository.  Since we store our trust store passwords encrypted I could not specify it on the command line with the -Djavax.net.ssl.* parameters.  I was setting these properties programmatically in my SpringBoot application.  But since the launcher already initialized the stack (when these params were null), it was not considering my trust stores.  When I switched to using --thin.offline everything worked as expected.  Using a combination of dry run and offline will do the trick for me.  I just thought I'd point this out in case others face this problem.  Not sure that there is anything that the thin launcher can/should do in these situations 
solution:

issue: @wilkinsona  I have Spring Security enabled and the SecurityConfiguration class has the configuration as shown below..```@Override    protected void configure(HttpSecurity http) throws Exception {        http                .csrf()                .disable()                .headers()                .frameOptions()                .disable()                .and()                .sessionManagement()                .sessionCreationPolicy(SessionCreationPolicy.STATELESS)                .and()                .requestMatcher(EndpointRequest.toAnyEndpoint()).authorizeRequests()                .anyRequest().hasRole("SYSTEMADMIN")                .and()                .requestMatcher(PathRequest.toStaticResources().atCommonLocations()).authorizeRequests()                .anyRequest().hasRole("SYSTEMADMIN")                .and()                .requestMatcher((EndpointRequest.to("health", "info"))).authorizeRequests()                .anyRequest().hasRole("SYSTEMADMIN")                .antMatchers("/api/**").authenticated()                .and()                .cors();    }``` [![Screen Shot 2018-05-30 at 10.25.24 AM.png](https://files.gitter.im/spring-projects/spring-boot/VYI2/thumb/Screen-Shot-2018-05-30-at-10.25.24-AM.png)](https://files.gitter.im/spring-projects/spring-boot/VYI2/Screen-Shot-2018-05-30-at-10.25.24-AM.png) and this is the Role that is generated in the request

issue: Hello, guys. I got a problem here with Spring Kafka component.So, I have this producer config:```@Profile("kafka-producer")@Configuration@EnableKafkapublic class KafkaProducerConfig { @Value("${kafka.producer.server}") protected String kafkaServer; @Bean public KafkaTemplate<Integer, String> kafkaTemplate() {  ProducerFactory<Integer, String> pf = new DefaultKafkaProducerFactory<>(producerProperties());  return new KafkaTemplate<>(pf); } private Map<String, Object> producerProperties() {  Map<String, Object> props = new HashMap<>();  props.put(ProducerConfig.BOOTSTRAP_SERVERS_CONFIG, Arrays.<Object> asList(kafkaServer));  props.put(ProducerConfig.KEY_SERIALIZER_CLASS_CONFIG, StringSerializer.class);  props.put(ProducerConfig.VALUE_SERIALIZER_CLASS_CONFIG, StringSerializer.class);  return props; }}```According to docs, now I can simply do the following:```@Profile("kafka-producer")@Componentpublic class KafkaBroadcaster { @Autowired private KafkaTemplate<String, String> kafkaTemplate;}```The problem is that `kafkaTemplate` autowired var is getting initialized before `KafkaTemplate` bean from `KafkaProducerConfig`.I know that Spring would initialize `KafkaProducerConfig` if it sees that autowired `kafkaTemplate` var belongs to that class. The problem here is that it is actually `org.springframework.kafka.core.KafkaTemplate<String, String> kafkaTemplate;`I was following this docs: https://docs.spring.io/spring-kafka/reference/htmlsingle/#quick-tour

solution: 

issue: I'm by no means expert on maven, but according to the docs, if somebody adds the actuator and pulls therefore transitively the logging dependency, he/she would need to exclude it explicitly there as well or am I wrong? 
solution: 

issue: I think you are wrong. The exclusion in the docs for Maven will apply whenever `spring-boot-starter` is seen in the dependency graph IIRC, with Gradle the exclusion has to either be specified once for each time `spring-boot-starter` appears in the graph or it needs to be declared configuration-wide as you have done That’s not exactly equivalent, but it’s probably the most concise way to get what you want 
solution: 

issue: https://docs.spring.io/spring-boot/docs/current/reference/html/howto-logging.html#howto-configure-log4j-for-logging right? Ah I see there is an `exclusions` block yeah, for gradle the equivalent is the global configuration I guess :D at least I don't know any better way Thanks a lot for you support. I will create an issue in the project then

issue: Hi all, I have a question regarding the latest boot release 2.0.3 . After upgrading, it seems that the vcap properties are not retrieved anymore deploying it in Cloud Foundry (available as application.properties). Does anyone noticed the same? 
solution: 

issue: Are there any plans to make @Mockbean and @Spybean not recreate Spring Context everytime a new test comes up with a different set of mocked beans? This would massively speed up a lot of CI pipelines. 
solution: @jaakko-solita Strictly speaking, it’s not every time a new test comes up. It’s everytime a new combination of mocked or spied beans is used. The problem is that changing the beans that are mocked or spied, changes the set of beans that are available for dependency injection. A new context is needed so that dependency injection is performed using the right set of beans.. 

issue: so camel's zipkin spring boot thing uses wildcard mappings to properties ```# the zipkin service namecamel.zipkin.server-service-mappings.*=service1camel.zipkin.client-service-mappings.*=service2``` like ^^ 
solution: so the above wildcard things wired into a config properties type like `private Map<String, String> clientServiceMappings`.

solution: 

issue: If you are, thread dumps taken at regular intervals during startup will make it obvious as you’ll see `SecureRandom` in the stacks Looks like Docker is affected by the same problem: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/26021181/not-enough-entropy-to-support-dev-random-in-docker-containers-running-in-boot2d 
solution: 

issue: (a common work-around is to use `/dev/urandom` instead. It should never block.) 
solution: I hestitate to recommend that workaround as it can have an impact on your application’s security. People who know why more than I do about random number generation seem to be split on whether or not it’s worth worrying about.

solution: 

issue: need your feedback:Am I doing this properly?``` @Autowired protected Set<TransactionTypeProcessor> supportedTransactionTypes;  public TransactionTypeProcessor getProcessor(String clazz)  {  return supportedTransactionTypes    .stream()    .filter(type -> type.getClass().getSimpleName().equals(clazz))    .findFirst()    .orElseThrow(() -> new IllegalArgumentException("Transaction type not supported")); }``` I just stripped down my controller from 900 lines to 300 with this 
solution: 

issue: few things:- Remove `throws` from method signature ( we dont need that for unchecked exceptions)- you can use `.stream().anyMatch(type -> type.getClass() == clazz)` yea my bad…`findFirst()` is fine 
solution: 

issue: Ok, so - we’re getting this warning every time a RestClient is sending a request with a Protobuf payload (`Failed to evaluate Jackson deserialization for type […]`). There’s no error, and the payload is successfully sent in the correct format. It seems that it’s `org.springframework.http.converter.json.AbstractJackson2HttpMessageConverter#logWarningIfNecessary` that writes this warning when the `RestTemplate` tries to guess which accept-header to set (in `org.springframework.web.client.RestTemplate.AcceptHeaderRequestCallback#doWithRequest`). It does this by looping through all `HttpMessageConverter` beans to check if they support the payload type. Which `MappingJackson2HttpMessageConverter` doesn’t (but it still insists on logging the warning). 
solution: 

issue: I’ve tried setting the logging-level to ERROR for the MappingJackson2HttpMessageConverter, but that doesn’t take. I’ll dig into that - but in the mean time — does any recognize the issue and have a good work-around? :) 
solution: 

issue: (fyi - solved that logging issue.. was trying to set it from an auto configuration using `@PropertySource`. That doesn’t work. However, using an ApplicationContextInitializer in the autoconfiguration module works fine) 
solution: 

issue: Using `@PropertySource` with Spring Boot is not recommended (for namely the reason you’ve just discovered) 
solution: 

issue: You should probably try to get rid of the NoopHostnameVerifier. If you’re not checking that the SSL certificate’s hostname matches the hostname that you called, then you could actually be calling anything.

solution: 

issue: @chad_d_stud_twitter I believe it is the OS that is removing the folder after some time since tomcat puts it in the OS' temp directory by default. In my case this is happening on an AWS EC2 instance. But tomcat doesn't recreate the folder if it gets deleted and I'd rather keep the folder in the temp files so it clears out the files periodically. Here is an issue created on Github that explains what is happening. https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/issues/9616

solution: 

issue: The fact the server’s running in a container should make no difference. As long as the client trusts the server’s certificate and that the hostname in the certificate matches the name of the host to which the client sent the request it should work.

issue: Hi, there is some way to customize the generated manifest.mf file when running `gradle bootRun`? 
solution: 

issue: @mzcu I don’t believe there is one. You can get the remote side using `org.springframework.http.server.reactive.ServerHttpRequest.getRemoteAddress()` but I don’t believe there’s a local equivalent. That said, if you’re happy dropping down to some code that’s more container-specific, you may be able to get at something via `getNativeRequest()` 
solution: 

issue: If I have an application where we use `RestTemplate` which is more or less deprecated, but we don't want to make that code reactive and at the same time don't lose any Spring magic – is using `WebClient` with `block()`the way going forward?
solution: `RestTemplate` is not really deprecated. It's just that we won't evolve it in the future. So sticking to `RestTemplate` is perfectly valid if it does what you need. Another way to put that is that if you need specific usage patterns like streaming, scatter/gatter or custom timeouts, this won't be covered by `RestTemplate` and you need to use `WebClient` instead. Now using `WebClient` in a blocking application is fine too. Using `block()` shouldn't hurt there and Spring MVC controller do partially support reactive return types.

issue: @BernhardPosselt slf4j is not a logging library. The main ones are Logback and Log4j 2
solution:

issue: I'm using spring boot 2.4.1 and when i add the BufferingApplicationStartup like in the example and enable the startup endpoint, exception is thrown which says that BufferingApplicationStartup bean can't be found. Any idea how to solve this?
solution:  Maybe you are using BootstrapApplicationListener which build the application context again but ignores the previous applicationStartup, so it sets the default, this is a bug in spring-cloud-context:3.0.0

issue: Hi all, I'm trying to configure spring boot to use two datasources - as described in https://docs.spring.io/spring-boot/docs/current/reference/html/howto-data-access.html However, I'm having problems with it. ```@Bean@Primary@ConfigurationProperties("app.datasource")public DataSourceProperties dataSourceProperties() { return new DataSourceProperties();}@Bean@ConfigurationProperties("app.datasource2")public DataSourceProperties dataSource2Properties() { return new DataSourceProperties();}@Bean@Primary@ConfigurationProperties("app.datasource")public HikariDataSource dataSource() { return dataSourceProperties().initializeDataSourceBuilder().type(HikariDataSource.class).build();}@Bean@ConfigurationProperties(prefix = "app.datasource2")public HikariDataSource dataSource2() { return dataSource2Properties().initializeDataSourceBuilder().type(HikariDataSource.class).build();}``` The datasource properties aren't populated with the values from application.yml```app:  datasource:    url: jdbc:mariadb://xxxxxxxxxxxxxx    username: xxxxxxxxx    password: xxxxxxxxx  datasource2:    url: jdbc:mariadb://xxxxxxxxxxxxxx    username: xxxxxxxxx    password: xxxxxxxxx``` Any ideas what I'm doing wrong? Don't know it it makes a difference, but web part is turned off``` spring:  main:    web-application-type: NONE``` and it's using webflux starter I also tried getting those values directly using @Value (as that work without problems in other parts of the application)However, they're still not populated Is it possible that property source for application.yml is not yet initialized in @Configuration class? I also tried adding `@PropertySource("classpath:/application.yml")` to configuration class, but it didn't make a difference Yes, in `/src/main/resources` The app was working fine with a single (autoconfigured) datasource Now I needed to introduce another, and can't get past configuration 
solution: 

issue: nope That error looks like it’s ignoring that code completely and the regular `DataSourceAutoConfiguration` is kicking in try to replace `app.datasource` by `spring.datasource` to see if that changes anything > And if I manually populate them in `public DataSourceProperties dataSourceProperties()` it works. I missed that. Then that yaml is not read I guess. 
solution: 

issue: @BALAJI1183 the answer also mentions a `ReadTimeoutHandler` @BALAJI1183 also, `Flux.timeout` is about throwing a timeout exception if the time between two elements is too long, whereas the read timeout at the netty level is about throwing an exception if you don't get data at all for a given time. Subtle difference, but can be important depending on your use case.Typically, if you're using a transport protocol that's sending padding information over the wire (to avoid the connection from being closed) and you're streaming data as it comes - both timeout configurations will behave differently

solution: 

issue: Just to conclude here, registering your servlets in the application context doesn’t mean they are “mapped to Spring”. We register the servlets as regular servlets directly to the container. So having a dispatcherservlet on `/` and individual servlets to whatever mapping you need will work

issue: @snicoll oic, thanks. Curious, does "web flux" not work with `MockMvc`? and `WebTestClient` only works with a non mock server? 
solution: If you want a `WebTestClient` that works against your context, add `@AutoConfigureWebTestClient` (as you’d have to add `AutoConfigureMockMvc` in a MVC app). 

issue: hmm...  is `WebTestClient` poised in some way to replace `MockMvc`? are they just alternatives? or is there a strong reason to use one over the other? 
solution: 

issue: Yes, and `PropertyMapper` would be helpful for that I got that from the beginning 
solution: 

issue: exactly, you can do either way, we just felt we had a little better control of things using explicit bean definitions in our configuration classes. We also had a lot legacy projects that were not structured via the standard "boot way" and were doing things like component scanning from a generic root package "com.company.*" and they were unintentionally picking up shared beans. I think if you strongly encourage your 3rd-party users to use the standard boot layout and to also use `@SpringBootApplication` this would not be much of an issue. Legacy code, got to love it. 8)

solution: I have a controller with a method that forwards a request like this:```@GetMapping("/internal/hystrix.stream")public ModelAndView forwardHystrixStream(Map<String, Object> model) {    return new ModelAndView("forward:" + managementBasePath + "/hystrix.stream", model);}```Is it possible to implement a functionally identical method using WebFlux instead of MVC?. 

issue: @breun the `ModelAndView` equivalent in WebFlux is `org.springframework.web.reactive.result.view.Rendering`; I think it does support redirection but not forwarding; if I remember correctly, forwarding is a Servlet concept that we chose not to support in WebFlux.

solution: What's the best place to raise an issue agains the core spring framework?This line -> https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-framework/blob/280da61d5c9594e6541725ea67af9dda1a5943a7/spring-core/src/main/java/org/springframework/core/MethodParameter.java#L781Can generate an Index Out of Bounds Exception when using an inner class `@Configuration` because there is a constructor parameter at index 0, but with Kind 'INSTANCE' representing the outer class.  However this is filtered out by the above line, right before trying to access it after filtering at this line https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-framework/blob/280da61d5c9594e6541725ea67af9dda1a5943a7/spring-core/src/main/java/org/springframework/core/MethodParameter.java#L783.

issue: @hughwphamill the issue tracker for Spring Framework is at https://jira.spring.io/projects/SPR @raj there are no rooms for Spring Framework unfortunately. SO is the place to ask questions @dhaval24 there is no guarantee that `@PostConstruct` will run before all beans are created. It is invoked by the container once the dependencies for that particular bean are injected and before it is available in the context. That’s the wrong callback for whatever you’re trying to do. What is the use case? @dhaval24 not sure what you mean by escaping `,`. This is the default token to split items in a list. Is the target type of the property a `Collection` or an `Array`? @DoraRajappan I’ve replied you yesterday. Please move `UiApplication` to `org.life`

issue: @wilkinsona I changed the strategy from auto to identity on my entity and recreate the db schema and it works well now. Thank you very much. 
solution: 

issue: it will generate Q*.java files then i can work with them like so:```private final QTransaction transaction = QTransaction.transaction;private BooleanExpression amountSearch(float amount, float min, float max) {  BooleanExpression amountPre = null;  if (min > 0 && max > 0) {   amountPre = transaction.amount.between(min, max);  } else if (min > 0) {   amountPre = transaction.amount.gt(min);  } else if (max > 0) {   amountPre = transaction.amount.lt(max);  } else if (amount > 0) {   amountPre = transaction.amount.eq(amount);  }  return amountPre; }```

issue: Im so boring but I can't get a Hibernate SessionFactory in springboot  v-2.0.4.RELEASE，somebody can help？ [![image.png](https://files.gitter.im/spring-projects/spring-boot/cPVl/thumb/image.png)](https://files.gitter.im/spring-projects/spring-boot/cPVl/image.png) [![image.png](https://files.gitter.im/spring-projects/spring-boot/NNvb/thumb/image.png)](https://files.gitter.im/spring-projects/spring-boot/NNvb/image.png) and its working well in v-1.5.x 
solution: 

issue: As of hibernate2 the `SessionFactory` extends `EntityManagerFactory` which makes that code unusable. Hibernate 5.2 (I meant) Downgrade to an earlier Hibernate version to make it work, or don't use the `SessionFactory` but rather the `EntityManager` and unwrap that to the `Session`.

issue: @snicoll  Without devtools Spring's `JCacheCacheAutoConfiguration` is using a `Launcher@AppClassLoader`.Hibernate's `JCacheRegionFactory` is still using the `ClassLoading$DefaultClassLoader`.

issue: Hello all, I'm looking for some documentation around adding in oauth2 client to a Spring Boot app. I don't need security for the app itself. I've tried looking in the usual places but finding a lot of contradictory and incomplete examples. 
solution: 

issue: I'm using the latest version 
solution: @snicoll Yes, adding the below config worked:```@Configurationpublic class HibernateConfig {    @Autowired    private CacheManager cacheManager;    @Bean    public HibernatePropertiesCustomizer hibernatePropertiesCustomizer() {        return hibernateProperties -> hibernateProperties.put(ConfigSettings.CACHE_MANAGER, cacheManager);    }}```This way Hibernate seems to use the same cache manager. I'm noticing some other unexpected behaviour, but might be unrelated, so will dig into that.Note also the `/actuator/metrics/cache.gets` now return correct data like gets, puts etc., albeit very broad (not per cache).Did Spring Boot ever considered exposing JCache statistics as part of the Caches endpoint in case the user us using JCache?Anyway , thx a lot for your help!. 

issue: That’s more of a micrometer question to me It’s not really about JCache though, JCache is very limited in what they expose. 
solution: Which does not make it that useful to be honest. I would like to know per cache what the hit/miss rate so independent caches can be fine tuned. Yes that's more of a micrometer question indeed.. It’s not exposed for JCache because the spec does not expose that information (as far as I remember, it’s been a while). Check `JCacheMetrics` in the micrometer project. If there is something missing in there, please open an issue in their tracker. 

issue: But I also don't get meters using the JCache, ehcache, hazelcast, ...

issue: @PaulienVa thank you a lot! 
solution: 

issue: @PaulienVa I am not sure what you mean by “solved yet”. The warning is there to indicate that you have multiple org.json implementation on the classpath that could include an API variants and an issue at runtime The starter brings `jsonassert` that uses a json library. Vaadin uses a different implementation. To fix the warning, exclude `org.skyscreamer:jsonassert` from the test starter 
solution: 

issue: @davidkarlsen no need to ping Phil, really. It’s flagged for `2.1.x` so it’s our intention to merge it 
solution: 

issue: @snicoll don’t you think it is weard that org:skyscreamer uses a vaadin dependency ? ``` 
solution: 

issue: No I'm not. This is something new I'm trying to do. 
solution: enable actuator endpoints and fit them into our security model essentially.. 

issue: Oh you were not :) I was just trying to understand the reason why you want to do this. I still haven’t :) (IMO that’s not clearer) Using `@PreAuthorize` on features you don’t own is not a very scalable model IMO Neither of that happens with Actuator security. If you decide to use `@PreAuthorize` you don’t really have a choice of combining that with securing code you don’t own. Trying to extend code you don’t own so that it fits with your preferred approach doesn’t sound like a good idea to me. But I guess there’s not much else to be said on this topic now. What Eric said 
solution: 

issue: I agree, but I would also argue that combining `@PreAuthorize` with global configuration is messy. I would also argue that path matching all your endpoints in a single long chain call in securityConfig is not optimal. but I guess that is the only way to unify all the security config What I mean is that if I use `@PreAuthorize` for securing code I do own, and using the global config for endpoints that are owned by other projects is messy. I'm not suggesting extending actuator endpoints anymore, just that since method security is not available, it would make sense to convert my existing `@PreAuthorize` usage to the global config. 
solution: 

issue: How else would you do it? As @snicoll mentions you can’t annotate methods on code you do not own

solution: 

issue: hello spring boot team; is it advisable to use `reactor-http-nio-X`  threads for internal processing? E.g. all the I/O etc? I believe these threads are reactor-netty threads and should be used to receive incoming requests; not the internal processing. 
solution: 

issue: @nnanda2016 In a Spring WebFlux + Reactor Netty app, everything is done by default on those threads, unless you `publishOn`/`subscribeOn` manually. So: yes. Once you've scheduled work on a different Scheduler, I don't think we offer the possibility to schedule work back on those. 
solution: 

issue: i may be doing some blocking (e.g. JDBC) I/O tasks…so these threads will be blocked. my question was related to some reccommendation from boot team on these resource management

issue:  I was using boot 1.5 and it was working, now I updated to boot 2.0 and it's not anymore 
solution: i already tried all the flags of the universe :(. the only diff error i get is:> Caused by: org.springframework.beans.factory.BeanCurrentlyInCreationException: Error creating bean with name 'scopedTarget.dataSource': Requested bean is currently in creation: Is there an unresolvable circular reference?. 

issue: tried putting it in the test class ```Caused by: org.springframework.beans.factory.BeanCreationException: Error creating bean with name 'client' defined in com.potrero.g2r.phdb.EMRRepoTest$ApolloConfig: Unexpected exception during bean creation; nested exception is java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Could not resolve placeholder 'local.server.port' in value "${local.server.port}"``` 
solution: An EnumConstantNotPresentException is thrown when something tries to reference an enum constant by name when it doesn’t exist. The Proxy variant of it is thrown, in my experience, when there’s reflection involved. If you debug your app with a breaking point on the EnumConstantNotPresentExceptionProxy(Class<? extends Enum<?>>, String) constructor, you should see the class of the enum and name of the non-existent constant.

issue: You are correct, @edeandrea. `@EnableAutoConfiguration` has been there since the very beginning. solution: FWIW, I don't think the exception in #1573 is suitable for failure analysis. `HibernateException` is very broad and to be more precise with it we'd have to get into matching on the exception message which I don't like doing. There may be other bootstrapping failures where Hibernate throws something more specific..

issue: I am trying to fix an app to not fail if the redis cache is down. I have a @Configuration extending CachingConfigurerSupport overriding CacheErrorHandler errorHandler() with an CacheErrorHandler that just logs the errors. However, if I shut down redis the RedisConnectionFailureException exceptions are still thrown. It does not look like the error handler is called at all. Spring Boot 2.1.0... Any ideas? 
solution: 

issue: do you really need to parallelize to make saving of a list of objects faster? Possibly check out https://frightanic.com/software-development/jpa-batch-inserts/ Haven't tried the technique above in the article, as I haven't used JPA for a long time and can't recall, but in general batching of writes should be considered as opposed to threaded writes, you would have to compare yourself what is faster. Many databases also have some bulk insert/update interfaces for really fast insert/update of many records at once but that's maybe hard to access when using some OR-mapper and JPA... but sharing a JPA session across threads sounds like it could lead to trouble 
solution: 

issue: JSR310 is automatically provided now that Java8 is the base if you’re using the starter

issue: the xml is not mandatory 
solution: I would expect this to be the regular use case.. and I tried calling the ```bindCacheToRegistry``` and works perfectly (for users that would need to create a cache on the fly and bind stats). 

issue: Brian @bclozel it claims that the constrictor does not exist 
solution: @snicoll I will, my PR is almost meargeable, so I’m pinging back just after, thank you !! :). @karesti so the backstory for 5.2 is that we want to introduce an event that would be fired whenever a cache is created on the fly. Then Spring Boot could have a listener for that and call `bindCacheToRegistry` for you. If the `InfinispanCacheManager` is updated to honour that new contract, that would remove everything we’ve discussed.

issue: Sorry to spam again, but could someone in the spring-hateoas project have a look at this Q? JacksonTester is not being configured for HAL in a @SpringBootTest I've asked a Q over on SO could someone with spring-hateoas take a look when possible please? Thanks [<-LINK->]
solution: The auto-configured `JacksonTester` will use the context’s `ObjectMapper` which won’t have any of the Spring HATEOAS stuff configured on it. You might be better creating a `JacksonTester` yourself and passing it an appropriately configured `ObjectMapper` to use. I believe Spring HATEOAS has a module that it applies to the `ObjectMapper` to configure it. If you get stuck with that, asking in spring-projects/spring-data is probably your best bet as Spring HATEOAS is maintained by the Data team due to it being used by Spring Data REST.

issue: When service is Down actuator should return "Down " message but I am not getting any thing

issue: Remember, if the app itself is down the actuator endpoint is also down and will not be able to report anything... Only dependency healthchecks like the database, diskspace etc will be reported down

issue: Hi! I have a small question: is there any way to register a "Caffeine Cache" in Spring Actuator? There are more details here: [<-LINK->]
solution: Use CacheManager, but `CacheManager` only has methods to get caches, no? I cannot register a new one. Add your custom cache into CacheManager, inject CacheManager and get that cache out for your usage [<-LINK->].

issue: @DoraRajappan On the face of it, that looks like a problem with your query method. That could either be because your method name doesn't match the properties of the entity, or that you've defined a custom `@Query` annotation and it doesn't match the entity. I can't tell which of those it might be as you haven't provided enough information. I think you'd probably be best asking in the spring-projects/spring-data channel and providing some more information about all the pieces that are involved. I'm struggling to see any connection between the two. Can you share a minimal example that behaves as you've described?

issue: @kibbled the `it `is the serverResponse and its respponseBody is always null... so I can’t check the message send back from the handler... 
solution: > You're passing the system property into the JVM that's running Maven and that JVM isn't always the one that runs your app as a new JVM may be forked. You should use `mvn spring-boot:run -Dspring-boot.jvmArguments="-Dserver.port=9990"` instead. I'd recommend always doing that, irrespective of the use of DevTools, so that you're not relying on the forking behaviour.@wilkinsona I tried with ` -Dspring-boot.jvmArguments="-Dserver.port=9990"` but Tomcat still binds to 8080 with DevTools..

solution: 

issue: i find OkHttp MockWebServer to be “clunky” in that regard whereas WireMock more closely aligns with `MockRestServiceServer` except it separates the stubs from the verifications, whereas with `MockRestServiceServer` you set up the stubs & expectations in the same step and for verification just call `verify()` just my 2 cents! 
solution: 

issue: @4goodapp If you are just starting out and in a position to choose what to use for your views, I wouldn't recommend using JSPs 
solution: @4goodapp I’d agree with @wilkinsona’s comment. JSP would be the last view I would recommend. Thymeleaf/Freemarker are much better. Thymeleaf is probably the most popular, but I think you'll have a better experience with any of the template engines listed on start.spring.io than if you use JSPs. So pick one of Thymeleaf, FreeMarker, Mustache, or Groovy templates. I'd probably avoid the latter unless you're using Groovy elsewhere..

issue: @snicoll > The bean 'service.FeignClientSpecification', defined in null, could not be registered. A bean with that name has already been defined in null and overriding is disabled.Action:Consider renaming one of the beans or enabling overriding by setting spring.main.allow-bean-definition-overriding=true okay this error is new 
solution: 

issue: There's no need to move them. Just put them in `src/main/webapp`. A war project (Maven or Gradle) will automatically include files in `src/main/webapp` in the root of the packaged war. 
solution: 

issue: Ok thanks. The thing is that then it won't work for the `.jar` packaging if someone decides to fork the app and use that packaging. I was hoping for a solution that would work for both, sorry for not being explicit enough about it 
solution: I wouldn't worry about that until it becomes a problem. If you want to deal with it now, you can move the resources out into `META-INF/resources` of a separate module and depend upon it. The module will then be packaged in `WEB-INF/lib` (war) or `BOOT-INF/lib` (jar). The servlet spec requires that resources be loaded from `META-INF/resources` of dependencies in `WEB-INF/lib`. Boot extends that to cover dependencies in `BOOT-INF/lib` for an executable jar.. 

issue: Exception on startup 
solution: `EndpointMvcAdapter` does not exist in Spring Boot 2.x. You must have something on the classpath that requires Spring Boot 1.x..

solution: 

issue: hi. can anybody tell me what I'm doing wrong here: https://github.com/domi55/spring-boot-docker-demo somehow the `docker build` command does not work for me and returns``` 
solution: 

issue: @domi55 Building an application inside a Docker container and then running it is a little unusual. Do you really want Maven and your application's source to be available in the environment where it's running? It's more typical to build the application outside of the container and then add the built binary to the container. With that said, the problem is that your `ADD src ./` results in `src` being stripped off so you have `./main/java` in your container not `./src/main/java`. Changing it to `ADD src ./src` will fix it. @ksgr999 That's a Wildfly bug or limitation. It can't cope with `module-info.class` files for the module system that's available in Java 9 and later. Wildfly 10 is almost 3 years old. Hopefully a more up-to-date version will have fixed the problem. 
solution: 

issue: Has someone noticed a decrease in Performance between Spring Boot 2.0.4 vs 2.0.5+ when running in Docker? Not sure what the actual problem, is but scanning within custom dispatcher servlets has decreased a lot for us. Initialising the servlet went from under 1s to 10 or more seconds. Boot 2.1 is fine 
solution: 

issue: @gitmnd because UTF-8 is the default encoding for JSON, as specified in the RFC

issue: My custom exception is totaly ignored, after its throwing  `ResponseEntityExceptionHandler.handleException` is called just after But my exception was thrown first The request flow should stop after my custom exception, am I wrong? I hope it doesn't try to convert the exception ^^ 
solution: 

issue: What I do is I override the underlying protected methods from ResponseEntityExceptionHandler and then check the cause of the exception. Your customer one should be the cause Your custom exception should be the cause of it Which to me actually seems like expected behavior Would be considered a type conversion error I think what's happening is spring is catching your exception and because it's happening during type conversion it's creating a type conversion exception with your custom one as the cause and throwing that. No different than if the payload had a string field that was supposed to be mapped to an int You can't convert a string to an int, so the end result would be the samr That's what I thought 
solution: 

issue: It actually seems somewhat logical to me. You are throwing an exception during type conversion (just like Jackson would be doing if it failed to do type conversion). Spring is handling it consistently Spring doesn't know your exception versus any other library's exception. It does the same thing for input validation I don't know what the change was between boot 2.0 and 2.1 (actually seems like a spring MVC change between 5.1 & 5.2) I really have to sign off for the evening but can continue a conversation about it tomorrow if you'd like Feel free to message me directly if you'd like 
solution:

issue: just trying to make sure it's before that ;) note: that has your `CommandLineRunner` code in it :/ 
solution: `CommandLineRunner`s run after the application context is successfully refreshed. This error is due to a validation failure of some required properties. In that case a `CommandLineRunner` won’t run.

issue: hello, i think i'm missing a very simple solution, but i just can't figure it out i have a 3rd party library that requires apache.commons.configuration object however, my code is written in spring, so i don't have a configuration object, i only have spring's Environment is there a simple conversion from environment to configuration? i looks a bit stupid to read the same configuration files that spring already parsed as configuration and then feed it to the 3rd party library 
solution: 

issue: as for the original problem of trying to convert properties to apache commons configuration, Spring does not use that library so as @snicoll states if you require that for some other library you are using then you’d have to configure it yourself or build your own adapter that knows how to translate Spring `PropertySource`es (or Spring’s `Environment`) to an apache commons configuration object. need to be able to see the test class along with the auto configuration class to help any further anytime! generally when i run into things like this i’ll create a small empty project and just bring in the bare necessities that are causing the problem…once i get it to work there then figure out how my “real” thing is different from what is working 
solution: 

issue: @timomeinen The system class loader isn't provided by Tomcat but by the JVM. As such, you can't replace it. 
solution: 

issue: You'll either need to change the code that's creating the FileSystem  using one of the overloads that takes a `ClassLoader` (https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/nio/file/FileSystems.html#newFileSystem(java.net.URI,%20java.util.Map,%20java.lang.ClassLoader), for example), or you'll need to package your file system implementation in the root of the Spring Boot fat jar. The latter is fairly easy with Gradle and a bit harder with Maven. 
solution: 

issue: @wilkinsona Thank you very much for taking time helping me. The problem with the overloaded method which takes a ClassLoader is, that the `FileSystemProvider` is not registered globally by `FileSystemProvider#loadInstalledProviders()` and upcoming calls of e.g. `Paths.get` will not find the provider. The reason is, that `loadInstalledProviders` uses `ClassLoader.getSystemClassLoader()` hardcoded.  The `FileSystemProvider` is provided as 3rd party JAR file. I will give the idea of putting it into the root a try. 
solution:

solution: 

issue: @davorm_gitlab I mixed up async and scheduling. The first uses `AsyncTaskExecutor` that’s not recommended for production as it creates a new thread per invocation while the latter uses a single thread by default (that’s why tasks were piled up without config). your executor, there is no need for that in 2.1, check the doc I just told you

issue: Hi Team, If I use @Transient for any field in @Entity class, it's value isn't gonna saved in DB. if I make some changes in an instance of this Entity class via setter methods and  retrieve an instance of this class afterwards, the value of the @Transient field for the object will not change right? What is the alternative here to change the @Transient field? Please clarify. 
solution: @RaviShekhawat The transient field will not be stored in the serialized object, but you can still modify it as much as you want as a normal class property.. 

issue: I totally understand, its not a code of mine, I was just wondering whether this particular change was intended 
solution: It’s an internal change of the binder. We’ve harmonized how stuff are processed in 2.0 so I wouldn’t call that an intended change but this looks more consistent to do that with regards to what we do with `.properties`.

solution: 

issue: @nWidart you need the actuator. Do you have that? @mikexliu can you start this app on your laptop or without Docker? (I guess so). Can you share the startup number? The actuator is the thing that auto-configures micrometer in the first place Micrometer doesn’t auto-configure anything, it doen’t know about Spring Boot anyway Fair but that’s a management feature that is tied in the concept of actuator in spring boot. Not all auto-configurations are shipped by default 11s seems quite a lot yeah. Twice as much means your 4CPUs aren’t really available or something 
solution: @mikexliu that’s not related to Spring Boot completely. The more classes you have the more chance auto-configuration can kick in for things you aren’t using. Loading a lot of classes can lead to poor startup time. 

issue: @snicoll yes. it takes about half the time: `Started Main in 11.413 seconds (JVM running for 12.572)`. still seems quite long but maybe this is the expected time

solution: 

issue: @RaviShekhawat it’s not very clear what you’re trying to do really 
solution: 

issue: It depends entierely of the cache store you’re using and the kind of db you’re using. Benchmarks are hard so unless you share the benchmark itself so that others can run it, I am not sure we can help you effectively The cache abstraction uses a by key lookup, you may want to switch to a different cache provider for a start Your DB has already a cache in the driver. if your HTTP endpoint does lookup by id, the DB should already be pretty fast to resolve those I am still not sure what you’re trying to bench with a lookup by id 
solution: 

issue: @snicoll Please suggest some standard way for benchmarking of my redis vs mysql implementation. 
solution: 

issue: There are other reasons to add a cache, but you typically add a cache in response to a performance issue that can't be addressed through other optimizations Think about it this way:  take any method/function that's performing slowly.  Now, put a hashmap in its scope and use that to cache the results.  Does the resulting code make sense?  Is it elegant/testable/maintainable/correct?  If not, don't use a cache 
solution:

issue: @josiahhaswell thanks is it intentional that the jackson message converter for jms doesn't use the same object mapper as the default system one? resulting in the need to pass it as so, because otherwise you can't customize the one on the converter?```   @Bean    open fun jacksonJmsMessageConverter( mapper: ObjectMapper): MessageConverter {        val converter = MappingJackson2MessageConverter()        converter.setTargetType(MessageType.BYTES)        converter.setTypeIdPropertyName("_type")        converter.setObjectMapper(mapper)        return converter    }```

I'm launching my application like this:```new SpringApplicationBuilder(Application.class) .initializers(new ContextInitializer()) .run(args);```And then in the initialize method:```@Overridepublic void initialize(ConfigurableApplicationContext applicationContext) {    Properties properties = createPropertiesFromEnvironment();    applicationContext.getEnvironment().getPropertySources().addFirst(new PropertiesPropertySource("properties", properties));        LOG.info("Context successfully initialized with properties");}```But that seems to not load the properties early enough for [this Azure sample](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/java/azure/spring-framework/configure-spring-boot-starter-java-app-with-azure-key-vault?view=azure-java-stable#configure-and-compile-your-app) to work correctly.However, if I remove the interface and supply the spring application like this and add my properties:```SpringApplication app = new SpringApplication(Application.class);ContextInitializerStatic.initialize(app);app.run(args);```And then the initialize method:``` public static void initialize(SpringApplication app) { var session = new ContextInitializerStatic();     app.setDefaultProperties(session.createPropertiesFromEnvironment());        LOG.info("Context successfully initialized with properties");}```This second approach works, is this an acceptable approach or will I shoot myself in the foot later?

issue: @jonbrmasson `ServerPropertiesAutoConfiguration` was removed in Spring Boot 2.0. It looks like `com.greenqloud.usage.Main`, or something that it is pulling in, isn't compatible with Spring Boot 2.x. I can't explain why it only happens in your Kubernetes cluster. Perhaps there's a custom condition that means something only kicks in in that environment? 
solution: 

issue: Spring Boot considers a database to be embedded if it's running in the same process as the application. Specifically, H2, Derby, and HSQLDB can all be identified as an embedded database. In Spring Boot's terms, EmbeddedPostgres isn't embedded. 
solution: That's covered in the next paragraph of the current documentation:> Setter injection should primarily only be used for optional dependencies that can be assigned reasonable default values within the class. Otherwise, not-null checks must be performed everywhere the code uses the dependency. One benefit of setter injection is that setter methods make objects of that class amenable to reconfiguration or re-injection later. Management through JMX MBeans is therefore a compelling use case for setter injection.. 

issue: The documentation answers it within the context of that version. But I'm trying to understand the switch from the older one. They both make good arguments Because, iirc, setter injection is for the optional dependencies.

issue: Good Night for All,I'm migrating my project Spring to Spring Boot. But I'm faced with a problem, we have a reverse proxy using apache and mod_cluster. In actual version we declare a Listerner in the server.xml.<Listener className="org.jboss.modcluster.container.catalina.standalone.ModClusterListener" advertise="false" proxyList="${proxyList}" />I put it like a Spring boot application.    private Connector ajpConnector() {        Connector connector = new Connector("AJP/1.3");        connector.setPort(8009);        connector.setRedirectPort(8443);        return connector;    }    private ModClusterListener modCluster() {        ModClusterListener modClusterListener = new ModClusterListener();        modClusterListener.setAdvertise(false);        modClusterListener.addProxy("10.1.1.34", 6666);        modClusterListener.setProxyURL(proxyUrl);        return modClusterListener;    }    @Bean    public WebServerFactoryCustomizer<TomcatServletWebServerFactory> servletContainer() {        return server -> {            if (server != null) {                server.addContextLifecycleListeners(modCluster());                server.addAdditionalTomcatConnectors(ajpConnector());            }        };    }But it don't work, the ModClusterListener want a LifecycleEvent of type Sever, but it never happen. Can anyone help me? 
solution: 

issue: @hdutra From what you've said, it sounds like `ModClusterListener` needs to be added to Tomcat's `Server` but the method you've used will add it to the `Context`. You could use a context customizer and navigate up from the `Context` till you find the `Server` or you could use a `TomcatServletWebServerFactory` sub-class instead:``` @Bean public TomcatServletWebServerFactory tomcatFactory() {  return new TomcatServletWebServerFactory() {   @Override   protected TomcatWebServer getTomcatWebServer(Tomcat tomcat) {    tomcat.getServer().addLifecycleListener(modCluster());    return new TomcatWebServer(tomcat);   }  }; }``` @gitmnd This room is for Spring Boot, if you have a question related to Spring Cloud, please ask in https://gitter.im/spring-cloud/spring-cloud In fact there's even a room specifically for Sleuth: https://gitter.im/spring-cloud/spring-cloud-sleuth 
solution: 

issue: @wilkinsona  It worked! Thank you a lot!

solution: 

issue: @chad_d_stud_twitter I would avoid `JSONObject` entirely. Generally we recommend returning a POJO and then allowing HTTP codecs (WebFlux) or message converters (MVC) to turn it into JSON. @sklaholz You can learn about the reasons for the restrictions in https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/issues/14773 
solution: 

issue: @chad_d_stud_twitter still it's a lot easier to grasp what your API returns. I've had the "joy" to work with systems that sent around some form of `JSONObject`both internally and via API and it's really tough to do anything if you're not the original author knowing what properties are used. There might be reasons to use such low level data structures, but if it's about your own parts fof the system I always would prefer actual objects that communicate what they contain and do 
solution: 

issue: when adding a health gauge to the metrics should `CompositeReactiveHealthIndicator` be used in a webflux app?

issue: i like the list because I often think "right, that would be useful as well" when I click through it. But I'm using the Idea-Plugin, not the website 
solution: 

issue: Yeah that’s the use case I’d personnaly like to move elsewhere. I don’t think the site should be used to discover what you can do because there are a bunch of things that aren’t there. There are, for instance, interesting 3rd party integrations we don’t list and not all projects are listed either. We focus on the getting started experience there which doesn’t give much space for things you may want to add when you have something off the ground. Again, there are much more we support or others support that is not on that list.

issue: I have this in my `WebClient` configuration (Spring Boot version `2.0.3`, reactor extra version `3.1.6.RELEASE`)```java.retryWhen(Retry.anyOf(RuntimeException.class, ReadTimeoutException.class)  .retryMax(maxRetryAttempt)  .backoff(Backoff.exponential(Duration.ofMillis(1000L), Duration.ofSeconds(30), 3, true))  .jitter(Jitter.random(0.9))  .doOnRetry(retryContext -> logger.error("[Retry count: {}][Retry Backoff: {}][Throwable: {}]", retryContext.iteration(), retryContext.backoff(), retryContext.exception())))```Our log file shows:```2019-03-26 10:37:21.878 [ERROR] Thread: reactor-http-client-epoll-16 [Retry count: 1][Retry Backoff: PT1.063S][Throwable: 1]2019-03-26 10:37:22.947 [ERROR] Thread: reactor-http-client-epoll-12 [Retry count: 2][Retry Backoff: PT5.663S][Throwable: 2]```I have couple of questions:- Does `WebClient` assign different threads for each retry? Or, is it possible?- Why `retryContext.exception()` prints numeric values like `1, 2` instead of the error message (if not stack trace)? 
solution: 

issue: @bclozel  we do not have `publishOn` or `subscribeOn` in our code. So, your explnation helps me understand the `(1)` behavior. But the point `(2)` is weird, `retryContext.exception()` should print the error message from the `Throwable` instance; not these numbers. Should I ask this in `reactor` channel? 
solution: 

issue: I doesn't sound specific to reactor, as the method signatures and types check out; the reactor team might help here. In any case, a small repro project will be useful as I'm not sure they'll spot the problem just by looking at this code snippet 
solution: 

issue: sure, this is happening in one of our production code (as part of a bigger issue related to `reactor-netty` which I am still analyzing). Let me see if i can put up a sample code. Thanks for the help. @bclozel Appreciate if you could provide some hint.- Does `WebClient` maintain any kind of connection pool? - If so, how to refresh/renew the connections in case they become stale (may be firewall or destination server has already closed those connections)?The context of these questions is, we are seeing a lot of `reactor.core.Exceptions$ReactiveException: java.io.IOException: Connection closed prematurely` in our server log and we are thinking it could be related to https://github.com/reactor/reactor-netty/issues/498 . 
solution: 

issue: @nnanda2016 Yes, WebClient (actually the reactor netty client underneath) is pooling HTTP connections. I'm not sure you can manually "refresh" those connections. AFAIK the connection pool might be unbounded and you can't just loop over the existing connections. For more about the actual behavior of the reactor netty connection pool, the reactor team should know better. Especially about when and how invalid connections are discarded. 
solution: 

issue: @iammohsinar is MySQL and the driver you're using supporting that feature? I'm aware of some datastores supporting this, like mongodb but it's not universal. https://docs.spring.io/spring-data/mongodb/docs/2.1.5.RELEASE/reference/html/#tailable-cursors As far as I understand, your code snippet is doing a "SELECT *" on that table and streaming the data (but not keeping the cursor opened)

issue: Found the issue. The additional metadata file needs to be copied to the the `target/classes/META-INF/` directory before running the annotation processor. 
solution: The annotation processor works as long as it is on the class path. For properties defined in scala the annotation processor needs to be called separately. But it works. 

issue: Nothing to do with relaxed binding please review the javadoc of `@ConditionalOnProperty` relaxed binding works for that or simple environment calls as long as the input uses the canonical format No, sorry That’s using the property, not declaring it

issue: Spring batch related question: Is there any reason why `JpaBatchConfigurer` is not extendable? I wan't to use a `JobLauncher` with async task-executor, but can't override `JpaBatchConfigurer#getJobLauncher` as constructor is protected. solution: 

issue: I don't think this is a problem with Boot's auto-configuration. It will back off when you declare your own `SessionRepository` bean It looks like a couple of Spring Session problems to me:1. It seems to rely on bean definition overriding to allow a custom `SessionRepository` to be configured2. When bean definition overriding is permitted, RedisHttpSessionConfiguration makes some assumptions about the type of the SessionRepository which do not hold true @herveDarritchon I see you've already been discussing this in https://gitter.im/spring-projects/spring-session. It would have been courteous to mention that to avoid people wasting time duplicating effort If I were you, I would open a Spring Session issue. Ideally, Spring Session would allow repository customization with bean definition overriding disabled. Putting that aside, I think a change is still needed to RedisHttpSessionConfiguration regardless I would guess, but can't tell from a truncated stack trace, that the property is coming from the bean definition So the question becomes, what has set the property on the bean definition?

issue: @snicoll I am using some @Value to check the value inside the yaml file 
solution: It could come from another source, that doesn’t mean that file was loaded. I can try to change the  value inside the yaml file and check easily if it is the value inside the yaml file. After testing (Change a property value inside my application.yaml), my new value is correctly inject in my @Value annotation. 

issue: Perhaps you have a `fwk-api` profile that is active. Sprig Boot will load `application-*.yml` automatically (making your propertysource useless) 
solution: 

issue: @hbrands Your second application context is hidden away in the `restServlet` `@Bean` method. When you create the `MockMvc` instance in your test, you're using the main application context. As a result, it can't find any of the controllers that are only known to this hidden context. Given that you're using `@SpringBootTest` with a random port, you could use rest template or web client and make actual HTTP calls to test your app If you want to use `MockMvc`, you'll need to get at the hidden application context and pass that to mock mvc 
solution:
