issue: @wilkinsona that's true I suppose. Though it's open source so not exactly hard to find. 
solution: Yeah, it's not hard to find, but they seem to be making it as hard as they can while still being OSS. We should respect that, I think.. With regards to pooling, yes, when using Atomikos or Bitronix, you need to use their connection pools. That's how the connections and the work that they do against the database get enlisted in the XA transaction.. You can still use spring.datasource.url and the like to configure the DataSource, but it will then be pooled by the transaction manager rather than Hikari. 

issue: Having spent ages on my multi-config db to get the hikari config applied properly... I'm just going to use a `ChainedTransactionManager` for the moment For my sanity

issue: @molexx Test contexts are cached by default. You can disable that using `@DirtiesContext`. You may want to review your test configuration and try and share it between test classes so that they can share a context too.

issue: Presumably your colleague also wrote some code that did something with it 
solution: In my opinion,I thought it should be spring.datasource.url but it's not. For full integration you probably want `@SpringBootTest`. 

issue: That's expected with `@WebFluxTest` which filters out any non-controller beans You'll need to provide a mock for the facade. You can use `@MockBean` for that You can't use a `TestExecutionListener` without any other Spring stuff. The `TestContext` that is passed to the various `TestExecutionListener` callback methods provides access to an `ApplicationContext`. 
solution: 

issue: aah okay so if i wanted to write more integration - like tests? what you suggested solves my problem btw :) thanks

solution: I am writing an open source library that will help with testing MongoDB apps, specially with Spring Data Mongo. One of the features I want is to dynamically override whatever the developer specified for the database name in the configuration, so if it was `mydb`, I'd dynamically change it to `mydb-test `or something like that.  I was able to find out how to intercept the `spring.data.mongodb.uri` property and override it with my custom URI. The way I am doing it is by defining `resources/META-INF/spring.factories`, specifying `org.springframework.context.ApplicationListener=my.custom.ClassName` where I am implementing `ApplicationListener<ApplicationEnvironmentPreparedEvent>` interface. That intercepts the property and re-injects it with the value I want back into the `ConfigurableEnvironment`. That's all well and good, however, I am obviously not guaranteed that the developer is using the standard spring property. What if they are defining their own `MongoClient` or `MongoTemplate` which is what they are using to execute DB interactions. Is there a similar interface I can specify in `spring.factories` and implement it such that I am defining the `MongoClient` (or whatever) myself and overriding whatever the developer did by default?.

solution: 

issue: @venkatasreekanth As of Tomcat 9, there's no acceptor thread count. Tomcat uses the connection timeout as the default for its keep alive timeout so you can use `server.connection-timeout` to set it. If you want the keep alive timeout and connection timeout to have different values, you'll have to use a `TomcatConnectorCustomizer`. 
solution: 

issue: @oknozor you may need a `@DateTimeFormat` on it as well

solution: 

issue: Hey guys, we were able to solve the issue why the list of EntityCacheStats was emtpy in the autoconfig. MeterRegistry uses a MeterRegistryPostProcessor which is looking for MeterBinders through an ObjectProvider ```(ObjectProvider<MeterBinder> meterBinders)``` to instantiate them. Through this call the EntityCacheMetrics was created.``` @Bean    public EntityCacheMetrics entityCacheMetrics(List<? extends EntityCacheStats> caches) {        return EntityCacheMetrics.of(caches); //public class EntityCacheMetrics implements MeterBinder {    }```` At this point Spring wasn't able to find and instantiate beans which implement the EntityCacheStats because our Config returned an ExtendedClientDetailsService (Interface)``` @Configuration public class EntityCacheConfiguration {    @Bean    public ExtendedClientDetailsService clientDetailsService(ClientDetailsRepository clientDetailsRepository,            StaticClientProperties clientProperties) {        return new CachedClientDetailsService(clientDetailsRepository, clientProperties);    }```The real implementation looks like this```public class CachedClientDetailsService extends EntityCacheService<ClientDetails, UUID> implements ExtendedClientDetailsService { //public abstract class EntityCacheService<T, ID> implements EntityCacheStats```It implements both the ExtendedClientDetailsService interface and the EntityCacheStats interface. Spring couldn't know at this point that the real implementation implements the EntityCacheStats interface as well.That's the reason why @Component and @Service worked because it returns the real implementation. 
solution:

Too much  message production for lower message consumption only because connections are badly load balanced...? Am I wrong ?

solution: 

issue: @peterluttrell_twitter assuming you're talking about the default error messages in Spring Boot + the missing context support in WebFlux: unlike servlet, there is no standard error pages at the server level. We've got error handlers which are tied to the dispatcher handler. The filters are applied before/after that in the chain and they don't know about the whole codecs+error handling infrastructure.You could technically achieve that, but you'd have to replicate quite a lot of infrastructure of the Spring Boot error handling. 
solution: 

issue: with that workaround you're getting the formatted spring Boot error response?

issue: ok, I didn't think it would - I thought you'd only get a 404, and not the JSON error response. Cool! This seems like a reasonable workaround in the meantime

issue: [![image.png](https://files.gitter.im/spring-projects/spring-boot/q19f/thumb/image.png)](https://files.gitter.im/spring-projects/spring-boot/q19f/image.png) Why is it always blocked? 
solution: 

issue: @pariaSadatHosseiny it means that Spring Boot cannot render the error page, since the application already started writing the response. At that point, we can't write the error page because it would lead to garbage content in the response. In this case, it seems that the HTTP client disconnected while the server was writing the response. There's nothing you can do here.

Then we have "AutoConfigurations" that import those modules configurations (unless it is api most of the stuff is package-protected).  In trying to keep the configuration consolidated to the modules and not scattered between the autoconfigurations, regular configurations, and/or using a bunch of static inner classes to guide the autoconfig, can I do something like this below?  *It seems the @AutoConfigureBefore/After do not get applied.*  If I recall, it does if I create static inner classes in the AutoConfiguration to guide it.In the code below, I would of expected an error because of the two same beans being registered but no matter what I do it looks like the DefaultHttpConfiguration is running after the LocalHttpConfiguration and because of the @ConditionalOnMissingBean not getting configured.   Our scenario we are trying to achieve is have one bean always injected (qualified by @Local) and then a @Primary one which is the default (file, s3, etc.).  Right now I am just trying to make sense of what can be done as a pattern for other AutoConfiguration/Configuration modules.```@Import(value = {    LocalHttpConfiguration.class,    DefaultHttpConfiguration.class})public class MyWebAutoConfiguration{     ....@Configurationpublic class LocalHttpConfiguration{    @Bean    //@Local    @ConditionalOnClass(DiskFileItem.class)    FileService<HttpServletRequest> localHttpFileService(final WorkingFolder workingFolder)    ....@Configuration@AutoConfigureBefore(LocalHttpConfiguration.class)public class DefaultHttpConfiguration{    @Bean    //@Primary    @ConditionalOnMissingBean    @ConditionalOnClass(DiskFileItem.class)    FileService<HttpServletRequest> defaultHttpFileService(final WorkingFolder workingFolder)```.

solution: 

issue: @kjq they're in different package, right? So this should work out as expected. 
solution: 

issue: Cool.  We dont use @ComponentScanning at all (for better or worse) and choose to explicitly define our @Beans.  Packages, like File/S3/etc, have a configuration that exposes the beans.  We then are using the AutoConfigurations to import those and when needed use conditionals to turn on/off certain injections.

issue: you could wrap the method calls on the thread pool executor in micrometer timers. issue: I have a spring boot application that has SSL enabled, with a valid certificate and key.  Requests work from within it's container.  From outside of the container, the SSL handshake fails (based on tcpdump/wireshark) the server terminates the SSL session immediately after the "Client Hello" message from the client.  I've got identical symptoms for both undertow and tomcat... does anyone have any troubleshooting suggestions?  enabling trace logging doesn't provide any additional details.  i'm at my wit's end.  other tcp based applications work properly from within the container, and this container shows the same symptoms in multiple container environments on different OSs.  any suggestions for diagnostics? 
solution: 

issue: @ruckc Did you enable the JVM's SSL logging or only the embedded server's? If it was the latter, you could try running with `-Djavax.net.debug=ssl` and comparing the output of a request from inside the container with one from outside. Another thought: are requests from outside the container being tunnelled to the correct port inside the container? I think the symptom that you've described would happen if you tried to use SSL on a plain HTTP port. @ruckc That's surprising. What client were you using inside the container when it worked?

issue: you can change them, but you can't remove them the thing is, once you start writing to the body the headers are committed and there is no way to change them anymore.

issue: @RestController@RequestMapping("/")public class EmployeeController {    // Assume this is a reactive database repository    private final EmployeeRepository employeeRepository;    public EmployeeController(EmployeeRepository employeeRepository) {        this.employeeRepository = employeeRepository;    }    @RequestMapping(value = "/employees/{id}", method = RequestMethod.PUT)    public Mono<Void> updateEmployee(            @RequestBody Employee employee) {        return employeeRepository.save(employee);    }  @RequestMapping(value = "/employees/{id}", method = RequestMethod.PUT)    public Mono<Void> updateEmployeeReactive(            @RequestBody Mono<Employee> employee) {        return employee.doOnNext(emp -> employeeRepository.save(emp)).then();    }}Is there any advantage of using "@RequestBody Mono<Employee> employee" above? solution: 

issue: @luanldt Your English is fine, don't worry. Without looking at your code I'm not sure if writing 20 separate implementations is necessary. It might be possible to abstract some code but you really might need 20 custom implementations to do what you want. In general, when I run into a situation like this I take a step back and consider if my design can't be improved to eliminate the problem a different way. This is why refactoring is so important.

solution: 

issue: @rbnjay You're on the right track. Classes in `BOOT-INF/classes` won't be found, only those in the root of the jar. If the jar is intended to be used as a dependency, whoever is responsible for publishing it should publish a normal jar in place of or alongside the fat jar that's currently being published.

issue: @cortizqgithub there is a `WebFilter` contract available in Spring WebFlux (see https://docs.spring.io/spring-framework/docs/current/javadoc-api/org/springframework/web/server/WebFilter.html). None of it depends on Servlet and it should be non-blocking, so you can't reuse existing Servlet filters for that.

issue: @masquino You can, but you need something to recompile your code so that the changed class files are available. Running Gradle in continuous mode in another shell is one option. @jgarcia12_gitlab Are you sure that you are using 2.4? `com.jayway.jsonpath.spi.mapper.JacksonMappingProvider` exists in that version. If you are using 2.4, perhaps its jar file has been corrupted, preventing its classes from being loaded.

solution: 

issue: @reneschroeder0000 Yes you can use it. It helps you manage all your exception in all your layers (data, service, controller). You also have to map your exception to HTTP code responses, mostly of the time it will be *BAD_REQUEST (400, for empty or null parameters)*, *NOT_FOUND (404, for empty or null value return)*, *INTERNAL_ERROR (500, for logic or other errors)*. Read this, I think it will help you : https://stackoverflow.com/questions/43124391/restcontrolleradvice-vs-controlleradvice, https://www.baeldung.com/exception-handling-for-rest-with-spring, https://www.toptal.com/java/spring-boot-rest-api-error-handling @sluongng Yes, just type Spring-Batch

issue: i have a controller that needs to consume a custom media type: ` application/vnd.oai.openapi+json;version=3.0`.  i add this to my consumes array, but when i try to make a request against the controller with that value in the Accepts header, i get back a `406 NOT_ACCEPTABLE` response. can somebody help me understand what other steps i need to take to support these media types? 
solution: @joshfix `consumes` means that the controller handler is expecting that type as a request body. You probably want `produces` on the `@GetMapping` annotation here instead. @bclozel that was it — i removed all `consumes` declarations from get mappings. in other areas, having a @GetMapping with consumes was producing a message: `"415 UNSUPPORTED_MEDIA_TYPE \"Content type '' not supported\”` when i send a request with the accept header.  simply removing that consumes declaration fixed that issue as well..

solution: 

issue: Perhaps you should take a step back and read a bit more about auto-configurations? 
solution: Something like this ```@Configurationpublic class GraphQLAutoconfiguration {    @Autowired    private GraphQLAnnotations graphqlAnnotations;    @Autowired GraphQLSchemaHolderConfigurer graphQLSchemaHolderConfigurer;    @ConditionalOnMissingBean    @Bean    GraphQLSchemaHolderConfigurer graphQLSchemaHolderConfigurer() {        return graphQLSchemaHolder -> {            graphQLSchemaHolder.initiate(                    event.getApplicationContext(),                    QLQuery.class,                    QLMutation.class,                    QLSubscription.class,                    QLQuery.class.getPackage().getName(),                    graphqlAnnotations);        };    }    @EventListener    public void updateGraphQLCustomTypes(ApplicationReadyEvent event)            throws IllegalAccessException, NoSuchMethodException, InstantiationException {        // User graphQLSchemaHolderConfigurer here    }}```. 

issue: Got it! Thanks. 
solution: 

issue: And if I wrap the `updateGraphQLCustomTypes` in a separate class which uses the `@EventListener` annotation inside - that will work as expected?

solution: 

issue: hence my code earlier has ```@PropertySource("classpath:config1.properties”)``` 
solution: 

issue: I think I found what's causing that, but don't know why it actually does?So when there's a custom WebMvcConfigurationSupport exists in the context, the WebMvcConfigurer instance is instantiated, but not used (`addInterceptors`) not called. There's no any `@EnableWebMvc` annotation, an empty `WebMvcConfigurationSupport` class is enough to cause the issue. But I don't understand it actually causes this issue. @wilkinsona can you please shed some light on this? Thanks ```java@SpringBootApplication@RestControllerclass SpringBootApp {  @GetMapping("/{id}")  public String getId(@PathVariable Integer id) {    return "OK";  }}@Configurationclass WebConfig extends WebMvcConfigurationSupport {}```This minimalistic app is enough to reproduce the issue that a `WebMvcConfigurer` coming from an auto configuration not adding interceptors 
solution: 

issue: Yes. Each artifact in both Boot and Framework can be used with Jigsaw as automatic modules. The benefits are negligible at best though so we don't expect many people to bother and have hardly seen anyone do so. 
solution:

issue: @OrangeDog Boot imports Spring Data's bom which controls the version for all Spring Data modules and keeps them in sync. solution: 

issue: @dylmeadows yes, see https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/issues/18828 and you should be using `spring.codec.max-in-memory-size`; it's pretty new so feel free to share your experience and what you were doing while hitting that limit. 
solution: 

issue: Just for reference, you can achieve the same manually:```ExchangeStrategies exchangeStrategies = ExchangeStrategies.builder()    .codecs(configurer -> configurer.defaultCodecs().maxInMemorySize(1024 * 10)).build();  WebClient webClient = WebClient.builder().exchangeStrategies(exchangeStrategies).build();```

issue: Does anybody know how to get Implementation-Version to show up in the MANIFEST.MF when using the spring boot gradle plugin? I can get buildInfo to work, but that still doesn't allow the StartupInfoLogger to print my application version 
solution: 

issue: Found it, it's not documented but it works. ```bootJar {    manifest {        attributes 'Implementation-Version': archiveVersion.get()    }}```

solution: so either `@MockBean` the properties too, or `@Bean` a real one. 

issue: I don't ever use `@SpringJunitConfig`. I'll use a Boot annotation, or not involve Spring at all. 
solution: 

issue: But what if you don't need all the auto configuration stuff ? That was my first question, should I use @SpringJunitConfig or @SpringBootTest for UNIT testing my services 
solution: 

issue: There are other boot annotations (like `@RestClientTest`) that only configure specific things If it's a service that uses a `RestTemplate`, then `@RestClientTest` is probably the one to use. If it uses JPA then `@DataJpaTest`, etc. then `@MockBean` that service, as you have 
solution: 

issue: No, there's no reason to use `@SpringBootTest` for this

solution: 

issue: ok, I solved my own issue: add `        this.setMessageReaders(configurer.getReaders());` to the ExceptionResolver and don't use annotated controller 
solution: 

issue: For version 1.5.14, what is the alternative to `<dependency>              <groupId>org.springframework.boot</groupId>              <artifactId>spring-boot-starter-reactor-netty</artifactId> </dependency>`When I wa using spring web socket with RabbitMQ message broker, I got `java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: reactor.io.codec.Codec` 
solution: 

issue: @ratikanta131 This starter has been introduced in Spring Boot 2.0.For the 1.5.x generation, you can take a look at: https://docs.spring.io/spring/docs/4.3.x/spring-framework-reference/htmlsingle/#websocket-stomp-handle-broker-relayThere's a section mentioning `org.projectreactor:reactor-net` and `io.netty:netty-all` - note the versions, as you can't use the latest reactor versions with that integration.Also worth noting: Spring Boot 1.5.x is EOL and security patches are not backported to that branch, and your application might be vulnerable to several CVEs (https://pivotal.io/security). Please upgrade at your earliest convenience.

solution: 

issue: @pmartycz We don't make a recommendation about annotation processor paths. Just do whatever works best for you. There's no property for the Spring Boot version as we don't want it to be configurable. I guess we could define the property and then not use it anywhere ourselves but I think that would lead to confusion about what it does. 
solution: 

issue: @joel.sina_gitlab I couldn't tell you about hibernateLazyInitializer  I never used it. But If a collection of your class is configured with FetchType Lazy and that collection is not ignored at the serialization step, when Jackson will call the getter, a select query will be executed if the collection is not already loaded

issue: well, as a framework, it should allow broader possibilities because server authors can accomodate that. issue: @Sebourg Does your entity object use the tobuider annotation of the "lombok plugin"? I also encountered the same error, just comment out the "toBuilder" annotation. issue: @sofocleous2_twitter Sorry, my answer in the reactor-channel about this was wrong. @Controller can indeed be used whether you have reactive or blocking endpoints (if I'm not very mistaken), e.g. there isn't a @WebfluxController or something like that but yeah, you can't mix the endpoint because either you run classic MVC or you run WebFlux. issue: `ZonedDateTime` does store timezone info... perhaps you're thinking of `OffsetDateTime`? `Instant` will always work to unambiguously represent the moment that something happened, which is usually why you're tracking created/updated

solution: 

issue: Single Database Cluster: -- This is not a preferred approach, as diff. services generally require diff. type of database need one may require cassandra, one may elastic search and one may be postgres. If in your case if all services are ok with same database type, still make sure that data tables of each service are completely separate and you do not take joins , only way to access other service data is through service call

issue: Not sure if this is a core java behavior or a spring-boot question but we have an issue with an async using the main thread when this async thread is called via an intermediate method. example: ```@FeignClient(name = "test", url = "http://localhost:8001/test/actuator/health")public interface BankProxy { @GetMapping(value = "/") public String cashIn();}```Then a service class:```@Service@Slf4jpublic class Component1 {    @Autowired    protected BankProxy proxy;          public void intermediateMethod(int i) {        log.info("{} intermediateMethod()", i);        callProxy(i);    }        @Async("adapterThreadExecutor")    public void callProxy(int i) {        String resp = proxy.cashIn();        log.info("{} callProxy() {}", i, resp);    }}```Main class```@EnableFeignClients@EnableAsync@SpringBootApplicationpublic class ExperimentsApplication {    @Autowired    Component1 proxy;     public static void main(String[] args) {  SpringApplication.run(ExperimentsApplication.class, args); }  @Bean public CommandLineRunner run () {     return args -> {         for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {//             proxy.callProxy();             proxy.intermediateMethod(i);         }     }; }   @Bean(name="adapterThreadExecutor")     public Executor asyncOutgoingAdapterExecutor() {         ThreadPoolTaskExecutor executor = new ThreadPoolTaskExecutor();         executor.setCorePoolSize(20);         executor.setMaxPoolSize(1000);         executor.setWaitForTasksToCompleteOnShutdown(true);         executor.setThreadNamePrefix("Async-Adapter-");         return executor;     } }```when i use proxy.callProxy() in the loop the thread for adapterThreadExecutor is created as expected. However, when I use intermediateMethod() it uses the main thread ([nio-8000-exec-“)

solution: 

issue: @kousen - I wouldn't say `RestTemplate` is deprecated yet, and really, for `TestRestTemplate`, all you're using it for is to send http requests to your app under test, so why not use it? An http request is an http request.  If `TestRestTemplate` fits your needs, then I'd say you're good.  If you're testing something that `TestRestTemplate` doesn't support (i.e. a streaming request or something more reactive) that would be something that forces you to use `WebTestClient` in my opinion. - disclaimer, I'm just an individual spring user, and those are just my opinions.

issue: @OrangeDog ah, that seems like it might be useful. solution: 

issue: @mehrentreich Improving auto-configuration of multiple DataSources is on our radar (https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/issues/15732) but not something that we have any immediate plans for. In the meantime, using a `BeanDefinitionRegistryPostProcessor` is what I would recommend. By that point, the environment should have been populated with the contents of `application.yml`. While you can't reference a `@ConfigurationProperties` bean in a `BeanDefinitionRegistryPostProcessor`, you can use the `Binder` API to bind the environment to your DataSource configuration POJO in a handful of lines of code. 
solution: 

issue: @cortizqgithub yes, documented here:https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-framework/wiki/Code-Style 
solution: some projects, like Spring Boot, also have automated code formatting and style validation: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.adoc#code-conventions-and-housekeeping.

issue: You said the converters are duplicated, that would seem to be the actual issue. 
solution: 

issue: including 2x `StringHttpMessageConverter`, 2x `MappingJackson2HttpMessageConverter` and 2x `MappingJackson2XmlHttpMessageConverter` (if you have jackson2 & jackson-xml on the classpath) but more importantly, they are sorted differently compared to  `new RestTemplateBuilder().build()` and that's what triggered my issue: if `jackson-dataformat-xml` is on the classpath, my app started sending xml data instead of json and I could not reproduce that with my tests, because my tests use the dependency-injected message converters

issue: > @kedar-joshi `log4j-jul` only does anything if you configure the `java.util.logging.manager` system property to `org.apache.logging.log4j.jul.LogManager`. Doing so has the benefit of allowing debug level JUL logging to be routed into Log4j2. `jul-to-slf4j` allows info and higher level logging to be routed into Log4j2 without any additional configuration.@wilkinsona Ah, that's neat. Thank you for the explanation.

issue: @ccellist wild guess: if you introduce e.g. `private static void realSetApplicationContext` and call it from your setter it might fix the error still unsure if you have to use static variable, can you elaborate a bit more? looks like you don't have to, e.g. https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-framework/blob/master/spring-context/src/main/java/org/springframework/context/support/ApplicationObjectSupport.java#L56 
solution: 

issue: > you should not reference a static unless it’s from a static methodDoesn't sound like a rule that you want. Instance methods referencing static fields is a really common thing. Otherwise you can't have sane constants or singletons. Though in your specific case, I don't see why you need a static. Just make your class directly `ApplicationContextAware` instead of using `ApplicationContextProvider`

issue: A potential fix would be to only inject the `CorsInterceptor` in the `AbstractHandlerMapping` if the handler extends `CorsConfigurationSource` AND it provides a non-null `CorsConfiguration` too.Right now this check is being done in `AbstractHandlerMapping#hasCorsConfigurationSource` Or another way would be to only add the `Vary` headers in the `DefaultCorsProcessor#processRequest` if they aren't already present.

solution: 

issue: @darek1024 that exception is not really related to the question I think. It’s ASM telling you you’ve not enabled the preview language features. Spring Boot itself hasn’t support for records yet (i.e. for Configuration properties). The framework team had a look but I am not sure where things stands. Make sure for a start you’ve enabled preview features and that you’re using the latest Spring Boot version.

issue: @Puspendert : I know that Hibernate has an `org.hibernate.exception.spi.ViolatedConstraintNameExtracter` and converts the SQLException to an ConstraintViolationException here `org.hibernate.exception.internal.SQLStateConversionDelegate#convert`. This exception should be the root cause of your DataIntegrityViolationException

issue: @konstantinblaesi it might be that versions are treated as semver, in such case pre-release versions according to semver have "lower value" then first release, so 4.0.0-RC3 < 4.0.0 in fact not semver, but looks like similar principle: https://docs.oracle.com/middleware/1212/core/MAVEN/maven_version.htm#MAVEN400

issue: w.r.t. `ClassNotFoundException: org.springframework.boot.system.ApplicationPidFileWriter`, that `ApplicationPidFileWriter` class moved from `org.springframework.boot.system` in 1.5 to `org.springframework.boot.context` in 2.0. so it definitely looks like something’s not matching up version-wise.

issue: Either way you have some serious code smell in there. I would think about how you can refactor this so you: 1) eliminate calls to statics to ensure your objects are as pure as possible and 2) avoid polluting the service interface with dependencies. I would instead introduce a new interface that uses the factory pattern to safely construct the underlying service.

issue: Hi. I just lost half of my hair debugging a problem for an hour :-). Not sure if it's a known problem in Spring or if I just found a new issue:```@Configurationpublic class SomeConfig {    @Bean(name = "other")    SomeOtherBean foo() {        System.out.println("constructing SomeOtherBean");        return new SomeOtherBean();    }    @Bean(name = "foo")    SomeBean foo(@Qualifier("other") SomeOtherBean other) {        System.out.println("constructing SomeBean");        return new SomeBean(other);    }}```With the above configuration class, SomeOtherBean is constructed twice, and SomeBean is never constructed. Why? Because the two methods have the same name. If you rename the second method to `bar`, everything is constructed once, as expected. Should I submit an issue? (Admittedly, using the same method name is not a good idea. I just happened to have done it by accident)

solution: 

issue: But when you do that you loose all dependency information, that’s why you should use real maven dependencies. When you do mvn install it’s put in your local mvn repo and you can get it locally from there using maven. BTW: when the jar is a spring boot jar, then this won’t work as you might expect, because this is an executable jar. To have a regular jar as well, you need to configure your build to do so. (google knows how to configure it to do that)

issue: @Marsyyh Boot expects `@ConfigurationProperties` classes to follow Java Beans conventions (https://docs.spring.io/spring-boot/docs/current/reference/htmlsingle/#boot-features-external-config-java-bean-binding). Following Java Beans conventions, a method named `getXxxxx()` should return a value, not `void`

issue: Hi all ... I'm facing a little problem like described here (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/37058691/encoded-comma-in-url-is-read-as-list-in-spring) - binding a list of Strings to a rest-endpoint where it must be possible to use "," in the String.  Anyone here have an idea on that? Currently we are using a workaround via ```@InitBinderpublic void initBinder(final WebDataBinder binder) {    // use the custom convert which does NOT convert 'A,B' to two entries.    binder.registerCustomEditor(List.class, new CustomCollectionEditor(ArrayList.class) {      @Override      protected Object convertElement(final Object element) {        // FIXME sometimes we get the value not URL decoded ... no idea why, does not happen in tests        if (element instanceof String) {          final String value = (String) element;          if (value.indexOf('%') > -1) {            // should not happen..            LOGGER.info("Must manually decode input value '{}', why?", value);            try {              return URLDecoder.decode(value, "UTF-8");            } catch (final UnsupportedEncodingException e) {              LOGGER.error("Cannot decode '{}' with UTF-8", value, e);            }          }        }        return super.convertElement(element);      }    });  }```.... but this looks not right because its a global "fix". Any ideas guys? 
solution: 

issue: @toidi There's no `spring.r2dbc.initialization-mode` property in Spring Boot. There may have been one in the experimental project, I can't remember. Please see [this section of the documentation](https://docs.spring.io/spring-boot/docs/2.3.1.RELEASE/reference/htmlsingle/#howto-initialize-a-database-using-r2dbc) for details of how to initialise the database when using R2DBC. It sounds to me like you will need to parse the request parameters yourself so that you can apply your own knowledge of the domain to figure out when values should be separated. You could just do that in the controller to avoid it applying globally. I've just double-checked and I can't reproduce the behaviour you've described I've got `@RequestParam("param") List<String> param` and `param.forEach(System.out::println);`. When I access `localhost:8080?param=1&param=2&param=3,4'` it outputs the following: ```123,4```

solution: I suggest looking to see if you can use EclispeLink instead of Hibernate. The former supports multiple datasources in the same context.. 

issue: @Decat-SimonA in that context, `A binding exists with kind` refers to a Cloud Native Buildpacks binding as documented here: https://github.com/buildpacks/spec/blob/main/extensions/bindings.md a binding is metadata provided to an app to describe a resource (database, messaging system, monitoring system, etc) made available by a platform. it can’t be provided at build time by maven or gradle.

solution: @narraboss  yes, you'll have to configure two DataSource beans for it. it's somewhat tricky,  imho.. 

issue: You can add an entry to `spring.factories` to include any configuration in a test slice You could either list it under the `org.springframework.boot.test.autoconfigure.web.servlet.WebMvcTest` key or the `org.springframework.boot.test.autoconfigure.web.servlet.AutoConfigureWebMvc` key. The latter will work as the former is meta-annotated with `@AutoConfigureWebMvc`. "it doesn't work" doesn't tell us much, unfortunately. It should work, otherwise I would not have suggested it. Without knowing what you've tried it's impossible to know why it didn't work for you.

solution: 

issue: Sorry, I don't understand what you mean. `spring.factories` lists auto-configurations that `@EnableAutoConfiguration` will import. It doesn't use `@EnableAutoConfiguration`. There should be nothing stopping you from using the `exclude` attribute of your single `@EnableAutoConfiguration` (or `@SpringBootApplication`) annotation to exclude the auto-configurations that you do not want.

solution: 

issue: Error message: com.fasterxml.jackson.core.JsonParseException: Invalid UTF-8 start byte 0x92  at [Source: (PushbackInputStream); line: 1, column: 163] 
solution: 

issue: @Andy Wilkinson Thank you very much. Weblogic.xml was the culprit. Added <package-name>com.fasterxml.*</package-name>, solved the issue.

issue: When using validation annotations like `@NotNull`, `@NotBlank`, ... you can override the error message via `messages.properties` by adding for example:```NotNull=Please enter a value for the fieldNotBlank.user.firstName=Please enter a first name```For a `LocalDate` that is annotated with `@DateTimeFormat()`, you need to use `typeMismatch=....` in `messages.properties`. solution: 

issue: The rules of Java apply: you have declared a field, and it's not initialized anywhere, so its value is null. If you try calling a method on fileProcessor, you'll get a NullPointerException, since it is null. So you must initialize it somehow. If it's just a regular class, you probably need to call its constructor. If it's a Spring Bean, then it should be injected into your controller. And the cleanest way to do that is to pass it as argument to the constructor, and of course initialize the field with the argument. Hi Iszubelle. You need to clarify your question: we can't possibly know how to implement a method without knowing anything about what it's supposed to do. Note that what you posted is not valid Java syntax.

issue: For the minimal version required, Boot1.x requires Java 7 at least, and Boot 2.x requires Java 8 at least. For each version, you can go to `https://docs.spring.io/spring-boot/docs/[version here]/reference/htmlsingle/#getting-started-system-requirements` and you'll get the Java version requirements for that version.

solution: 

issue: @kpcsuh just noticed that you said it was only failing for large requests. This looks a bit inconsistent. In my opinion, if it was 100% a TLS compatibility problem, the client wouldn't be able to establish a connection. Maybe this is not linked with TLS after all? It's hard to figure out the problem without any concrete element (like a stacktrace and log messages) @Zaker1 mockmvc is meant to test your Controller and its error handling. You're trying here to assert the response sent by the Spring Boot error handling infrastructure; this infra involves the servlet container so it's hard to reproduce 100% without a running servlet container. On the other hand, you're testing here the Spring Boot infrastructure, not your own code. See https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/issues/20345

issue: @snicoll, Thanks. I will check it. 
solution: You'll have to stop using `MockMvc` if you want to test against a real servlet container. Instead, you can use (Test)RestTemplate or WebTestClient and configure your `@SpringBootTest` to start the embedded web server on a defined or random port..

issue: I was able to figure out for customizing access log, by adding below 2 class files```@Componentpublic class ApplicationJettyServerCustomizer implements WebServerFactoryCustomizer<WebServerFactory> {    @Override    public void customize(WebServerFactory factory) {        ((JettyServletWebServerFactory)factory).addServerCustomizers((server) -> {            CustomRequestLogImpl requestLog = new CustomRequestLogImpl();            requestLog.setResource("logback-access/external.xml");            requestLog.start();            server.setRequestLog(requestLog);        });    }}@Slf4jpublic class CustomRequestLogImpl extends RequestLogImpl {    String resource;    @Override    public void setResource(String resource) {        super.setResource(resource);        this.resource = resource;    }    protected URL getConfigurationFileURL() {        log.info("Will use configuration resource [{}]", resource);        URL output = null;        try {            output = new ClassPathResource(resource, this.getClass()                    .getClassLoader()).getURL();        } catch (IOException iop) {            log.warn("Could not load resource [{}]", resource);        }        return output;    }}``` but I am not able to do the same for management server ... public class ApplicationJettyServerCustomizer implements WebServerFactoryCustomizer<WebServerFactory>this does not get triggered for management server

issue: I'm having a serious issue understanding what I'm doing wrong while invoking a Google GCP API from Spring using WebClient. It keeps complaining about `Content type 'text/html;charset=UTF-8' not supported for bodyType=com.mankyscooter.ticketaan.gcp.services.dto.GCPIdentityErrorResponse`. The offending code is  public Mono<GCPSignUpUserResponse> signUp(String email, String password, String tenantId) throws GCPIdentityServiceException {  final Mono<GCPSignUpUserResponse> response = webClient.post()    .uri(uriBuilder -> uriBuilder      .path(GCP_IDENTITY_SUFFIX_ACCOUNT)      .queryParam("key", settings.getApiKey())      .build())    .contentType(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)    .bodyValue(GCPSignUpUserRequest.builder()      .email(email)      .password(password)      .tenantId(tenantId)      .returnSecureToken(true)      .build())    .exchange()    .flatMap(clientResponse -> {     if (clientResponse.statusCode().isError())      return clientResponse.bodyToMono(GCPIdentityErrorResponse.class).flatMap(details -> Mono.error(new GCPIdentityServiceException(details)));     else      return clientResponse.bodyToMono(GCPSignUpUserResponse.class);    });  return response; }}. Anyone a clue where I'm going wrong? It only complains when the response is an error. To be clear, the confusion is specifically on how to parse different response bodies based on the HTTP status code as I'm trying to do here through `exchange()` and `flatMap`. I do not understand how it can complain about `text/plain` contentType not being supported even though it is used nowhere in the stack.

issue: Hi all. I'm struggling with an issue. In the code below a successful response serializes the response body just fine but in error cases the error body content is not serialized. Am I overlooking something :       public Mono<GCPSignUpUserResponse> signUp(String email, String password, String tenantId) throws GCPIdentityServiceException {  final Mono<GCPSignUpUserResponse> response = webClient.post()    .uri(uriBuilder -> uriBuilder      .path(GCP_IDENTITY_URI_SUFFIX_ACCOUNT)      .queryParam("key", settings.getApiKey())      .build())    .contentType(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)    .bodyValue(GCPSignUpUserRequest.builder()      .email(email)      .password(password)      .tenantId(tenantId)      .returnSecureToken(true)      .build())    .retrieve()    .onStatus(HttpStatus::isError, clientResponse -> clientResponse      .bodyToMono(GCPIdentityErrorResponse.class)      .flatMap(details -> Mono.error(new GCPIdentityServiceException(HttpStatus.resolve(clientResponse.rawStatusCode()), details))))    .bodyToMono(GCPSignUpUserResponse.class);  return response; }The error body that is being sent back to me does align with this schema :    @Data    @NoArgsConstructor    public class GCPIdentityErrorResponse {         private IdentityErrorContainer error;     private Integer code;     private String message;         @NoArgsConstructor        @ToString        public static class IdentityErrorContainer {                private IdentityError[] errors;        }                @NoArgsConstructor        @ToString        public static class IdentityError {                private String domain;                private String reason;                private String message;        }    }When I print the raw string in the error response body it is (for example) : ```{  "error": {    "code": 400,    "message": "EMAIL_EXISTS",    "errors": [      {        "message": "EMAIL_EXISTS",        "domain": "global",        "reason": "invalid"      }    ]  }}``` 
solution: 

issue: What's this got to do with spring-boot? 
solution: 

issue: ohh i am sorry think it have java related, will delete my question 
solution: 

issue: It doesn't look like it matches to me. The JSON has an `error` with a `code`, `message`, and `errors`. Your java code is mapping `error` to an `IdentityErrorContainer` that only has `errors`. In other words, I think `code` and `message` on `GCPIdentityErrorResponse` need to move to `IdentityErrorContainer` 
solution: 

issue: Sorry, got the months mixed up `@ExceptionHandler` or `ErrorDetails` depending on what you mean do that then 
solution: :(. 

issue: is good? sorry HttpStatus.INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR 
solution: 

issue: @DoraRajappan find below code. for custom application if you are using spring security then you should entry in configuration .and().exceptionHandling().accessDeniedPage("/errorpath"); public class CustomNotFoundException extends RuntimeException {}@Slf4j@Controllerpublic class CustomErrorController extends AbstractErrorController { private static final String ERROR_PATH = "/errorpath";  @Autowired public CustomErrorController(ErrorAttributes errorAttributes) {  super(errorAttributes); } @ExceptionHandler(CustomNotFoundException.class) public String notFound() {  return "error/404error"; } @RequestMapping(ERROR_PATH) public String handleErrors(HttpServletRequest request, Exception e) {  HttpStatus status = getStatus(request);  log.error("Request: " + request.getRequestURL() + " raised with " + status.value() + " code " + e);  if (status.equals(HttpStatus.NOT_FOUND)) {   throw new CustomNotFoundException();  } else if (status.equals(HttpStatus.INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR)) {   return "error/403error";  }  return "error/404error"; } @Override public String getErrorPath() {  return ERROR_PATH; }}

issue: Go and read the relevant documentation. It has nothing to do with spring boot, and we're not going to build your whole system for you. 
solution: 

issue: If you want validation to happen while receiving data, your library needs to evolve and accept reactive types. InputStream is a blocking contract and trying to make it work will expose you to memory leaks and worse.If you can't change the library, I think you could write the payload to a file and process that file asynchronously.

issue: alternatively, if this is expected, if someone could point me to the source (or docs even) of where this expansion is taking place that would be handy for my docs 
solution: 

issue: You can simply use the entity manager to query, instead of going through the DataSource to get a connection (which, if I'm not mistaken, won't automatically be the connection used by the current JPA transaction, and thus won't see what has been saved by JPA). Even if the connection was the JPA transaction's connection, you would need to call EntityManager.flush() to make sure that something is actually inserted in the table.

Just out of curiosity, I've found out that this is the SHA-1 hash of the stored file. I've also found the `org.springframework.boot.loader.archive.JarFileArchive#getNestedArchive` method that deals with the "UNPACK:" prefix (in the `2.3.x` branch on GitHub). issue: Are you using Spring? Use `RestTemplate` or `WebClient`. 
solution: Right, I'll look into them.  @OrangeDog. 

issue: JDBC uses blocking I/O underneath. What Oracle did was adding asynchronous/reactive methods to their JDBC driver that they call Reactive JDBC extensions. Those extensions are purely vendor-specific to the Oracle database driver. R2DBC is an independent specification that isn't related to JDBC nor is JDBC related to R2DBC. 
solution: 

issue: I think Spring Boot 2.4.0 releases in two days? it depends on Spring Framework 5.3.0 Spring Boot 2.3.5 depends on Spring 5.2.10, which should also have that issue that Brian mentioned covered

issue: If you're a customer/user of that vuln scanning product, maybe you can report that CVE as a false positive or at least as a "requires more context about the app" issue.Again, you could argue that all Java apps are vulnerable (no library needed) because they can deserialize Java classes from untrusted sources.

issue: maybe they didn't have a chance to test 5.2.10 and 5.3.0 yet.. 
solution: 

issue: @bilak just wondering if it makes sense to use liquibase inside a container with spring. wouldn't it be easier to convert it into `schema.sql`? 
solution: @seguri I just want to stick with current developement technique where we are using liquibase a lot. So for local developement it would be ok to use liquibase enabled. But for kubernetes I'd like to disable it and only use it as `Job` that is being executed once per deployment as mentioned before. But I'm open for better suggestions. 

issue: I did skim those links. As I understand it, Liquibase's locking is only a problem if a process fails before it can update the table to release a lock. Running it in a Helm hook won't eliminate the possibility of that happening, but it may reduce it a bit. If it runs on each pod creation and the DB is already up-to-date, the lock should be taken and then dropped almost immediately when Liquibase realises it has nothing to do.

issue: I use either `@EnableConfigurationProperties` where it will be used, or put the `@ConfigurationProperties` directly on a `@Bean` if it makes sense.As that guide says, they're only using `@Configuration` to make it an instantiated bean with minimal code. If it was just `@Component` then it wouldn't be created as it's not used anywhere.

issue: Thanks Brian. I'm not aware about "usual channels" -- I'm just subscribed to github releases ;-) 
solution: 

issue: that sentence means that if you run actuator on a separate port, your main app (on :8080) and your actuator endpoints (on :9090) can't share everything. For example, HTTP client connections aren't processed by the same HTTP connectors. This means that you could end up in a situation where your health endpoint on :9090 says "UP" while your :8080 is overflown with traffic and cannot process requests at the time 
solution: 

issue: @bclozel but metrics such db pool, jms connections are shared in both or not? not bug yet, but it's somehow confusing, because we don't know what is really included and what is not...so maybe there should be more about it in documentation.

culprit:```<dependency>      <groupId>io.zipkin.gcp</groupId>      <artifactId>zipkin-sender-stackdriver</artifactId>      <version>0.17.0</version>      <scope>compile</scope>      <exclusions>     <groupId>io.grpc</groupId>        </exclusion>        <exclusion>          <artifactId>grpc-core</artifactId>          <groupId>io.grpc</groupId>        </exclusion>        <exclusion>          <artifactId>zipkin</artifactId>          <groupId>io.zipkin.zipkin2</groupId>        </exclusion>      </exclusions>    </dependency>```

issue: Hello I need help I create a Spring boot with sub modules with Gradle (kt) and Kotlin When I run java -jar I have this error > aucun attribut manifest principal dans app.jarIn english : > no manifest attribut in app.jarDo you know what does it mean 
solution: 

issue: maybe the Spring Boot POM is corrupted on your disk. Try and refresh dependencies with `mvn dependency:purge-local-repository` in your project, then try building again. did you apply the spring boot plugin in the module that builds the executable jar? This can happen if the spring boot plugin is not applied and the app is not repackaged as an executable jar (with the bootJar task) 
solution:

solution: 

issue: Yes you can get around a restart by starting a second instance with the socket reuse option. Anything trying to connect to it will be none the wiser. Of course, if you have dependencies like database schemas or something built in then you may indeed need to shutdown the old instance first to prevent corruption.

solution: 

issue: if kubernetes is killing your pod when liveness probe is not available, then it probably makes sense. Or no? Liveness is something different from readiness. If readiness is not available, then only new trafic is not routed to that pod, untill it returns that it's ready to accept traffic again 
solution: 

issue: and for readiness I think the normaln endpoint is ok, because if application is under load and there is few requests being processed probably it won't respond immediatelly and that should be a good sign for kubernetes to stop forwarding request to it yes but I'm asking about different port for liveness and different port for readiness. I think that completely makes sense in kubernetes world. Liveness should respond everytime even when there's load on application and responses are not immediate. That means application is still alive but maybe under load. However readiness could be placed on same port where application is processing request, when kubernetes won't be able to reach readiness probe it will probably remove the pod from loadbalancer. Does this makes sense?

solution: 

issue: testing update from 2.3.+ to 2.4.1, Spring silently disabled matching of trailing slash. Is it a bug or an omission in release notes?```kotlin// controller@RestController@RequestMapping("/test-controller")class TestController { @PostMapping("/") @ResponseStatus(HttpStatus.CREATED) fun post(): String = "controller works"}// tests@Testfun `controller should work with slash`() { client.post().uri("/test-controller/").exchange()  .expectStatus().isCreated  .expectBody<String>().isEqualTo("controller works")}@Testfun `controller should work without slash`() { client.post().uri("/test-controller").exchange()  .expectStatus().isCreated  .expectBody<String>().isEqualTo("controller works")}```second test fails 
solution: 

issue: Even curiouser, turns out it was like that in 2.3.* too, but only for controllers, for router {} functional DSL slash was ignored. but after update to 2.4 it is not ignored anymore ```kotlin@Bean fun post() = router { (accept(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON) and "/test-controller").nest {  POST("/") {   ServerResponse.status(201).body("controller works")  } }}```^^ this works with tests given above in spring boot 2.3.* but doesn't work with spring boot 2.4.*

issue: https://gitter.im/spring-cloud/spring-cloud 1) Correct. In Spring Boot, a dependency on r2dbc-pool (as included in the R2DBC starter) is sufficient to enable pooling.2) No. There's no DB driver in the starter. You should add the one that's appropriate for the DB that you're using.

issue: Hello. Not strictly a Spring Boot related question but `spring-messaging` has an abstraction for that You could start looking at `MessageMapping` and the various implementations for RSocket and websocket in the Spring Framework code base. `Message` and `MessageHeaders` have the necessary abstraction for payload and headers. `org.springframework.messaging.Message` that is.

solution: 

issue: An executable war gives you more control as you're not reliant on someone else maintaining a version of Tomcat that's configured correctly to meet your application's needs. Instead, everything is in the war file and all you need is for Java to be installed. This makes deployment easier and less error-prone. Executable wars (or jars) are the recommended approach. 
solution: 

issue: @bclozel and, as I mentioned above, Spring Security does not support configuring x509 (or any other auth) for WebSockets in WebFlux yet, here’s the issue https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/5188 
solution: 

issue: Please post the code of the class you're trying to deserialize. A test with what you expect and what you get instead would be helpful understanding and reproducing your issue, too. 
solution: 

issue: I used the code you posted, verbatim (creating empty classes for the other properties), using the version of Spring Boot you're using, in a project created by Spring initializr and using the default properties and dependencies, and I can't reproduce your exception. You'll have to post a complete demo project reproducing the issue.

solution: 

issue: Properties in `application.yml` don't become system properties. They're added to Spring's `Environment` but won't appear in `System.getProperties()`

issue: alright thank you very much <beans:bean id="delegateMethodAccessDecisionManager"        class="org.springframework.security.access.vote.AffirmativeBased">        <beans:property name="allowIfAllAbstainDecisions"            value="false" />        <beans:property name="decisionVoters">            <beans:list>                <beans:bean                    class="org.springframework.security.access.prepost.PreInvocationAuthorizationAdviceVoter">                    <beans:constructor-arg ref="preInvocationAdvice" />                </beans:bean>            </beans:list>        </beans:property>    </beans:bean> 
solution: 

issue: It's not possible using a filter's url pattern. `/v*/**` style path-matching is a Spring Framework feature and the filter's URL pattern is handled by the servlet container. You could map your filter to every request and then write some code that uses Spring Framework's `AntPathMatcher` or `PathPattern` to perform the matching. That's an implementation of what I suggested above. Given the limitations of the servlet spec, I don't think it's hacky.

issue: @wilkinsona  For a webflux service, I noticed that in certain cases the response code received by the client is not the same as the one observed by a `WebFliter` on the `ServerHttpResponse`. Here's an example of this: https://github.com/flavium31/spring-webflux-status-code-demo . In this example, a `ResponseStatusException` is thrown from the controller which eventually causes the response code to be set to 418, but when logging the status code from the `WebFilter` the output is 200. I was hoping you could help me understand why this is.The reason I'm asking is that this seems to cause an issue in Spring Cloud Sleuth, which determines the status of traces it captures based on the `ServerHttpResponse` - so a lot of traces incorrectly get status 200. This was initially raised with @jonatan-ivanov here: https://gitter.im/spring-cloud/spring-cloud-sleuth?at=6011c56d55359c58bf049831 
solution: 

issue: hi, i am trying to under the below code in ErrorPageFilter ```private void handleErrorStatus(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response, int status, String message) throws ServletException, IOException {        if (response.isCommitted()) {            this.handleCommittedResponse(request, (Throwable)null);        } else {            String errorPath = this.getErrorPath(this.statuses, status);            if (errorPath == null) {                response.sendError(status, message);            } else {                response.setStatus(status);                this.setErrorAttributes(request, status, message);                request.getRequestDispatcher(errorPath).forward(request, response);            }        }    }```what will be the HTTP verb of the forward here. 
solution: 

issue: The `request` encapsulates the verb so it'll be whatever's in the request. 
solution: 

issue: Yes, it'll be a `POST` to `/error`.Boot's `BasicErrorController` uses a plain `@RequestMapping`. Yours should do the same. 
solution: 

issue: thanks again. but if my application exposes only GET and POST , can I just use ```@RequestMapping(method = {RequestMethod.GET, RequestMethod.POST} , path =  "/error") 
solution: 

issue: That depends on how you want error responses to requests that use other verbs to be handled. You may only expose GET and POST, but you can't stop clients from using the other verbs. 
solution: 

issue: Ok, so what are you looking for? That's a question for the Spring Data team. You can find them in https://gitter.im/spring-projects/spring-data 
solution: 

issue: Yes, you can. Configure your `RestTemplate` with a custom `ResponseErrorHandler`. It's `DefaultResponseErrorHandler` that's truncating the body. Unfortunately its `getErrorMessage` method is private so you can't override it and the maximum length is hardcoded at 200. That means you'll have to provide your own implementation. You may want to raise a Spring Framework issue to see if they'd consider making `DefaultResponseErrorHandler` extensible or configurable: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-framework/issues

solution: 

issue: *TransactionalEventListener* handling logic is spring boot specific  and triggerBeforeCommit is fired by *org.springframework.transaction.support.AbstractPlatformTransactionManager#processCommit* so its spring-boot specfic actually what I want is to implement auditing logicin prePersist() I will add transaction synchronization and in beforeCommit() I will send to Kafka lets say. In case of failure I will throw exception and rollback DB transactions also. Anyway I guess its not part of spec. 
solution: 

issue: @Transactional uses aspect oriented programming. Your Foo instance will be wrapped by a proxy that adds the transactional behavior, but this proxy behavior is only applied for calls that are not internal. So this.foo() will not get the transactional behavior, but a Bar instance doing fooInstance.foo() would 
solution: 

issue: Given that you're not using Spring Boot, please ask Spring Security questions in https://gitter.im/spring-projects/spring-security.

issue: Hello, guys, I encountered an issue regarding using Redis cache metrics in springboot 2.4.2. Anyone has clue about this? https://stackoverflow.com/questions/66358386/redis-cache-metrics-doesnt-work-in-springboot-version-2-4-2 
solution: 

issue: The docs show the default builder as the default value for the `builder` property: https://docs.spring.io/spring-boot/docs/current/gradle-plugin/reference/htmlsingle/#build-image-customization with Boot 2.4, it’s `paketobuildpacks/builder:base`. The Java-related buildpacks included in that builder are documented in the Paketo docs here: https://paketo.io/docs/buildpacks/language-family-buildpacks/java/ The Spring Boot docs don’t touch on details like JVM provider, version, etc because the Boot plugins are delegating all the real work of building the image to a CNB builder and buildpacks. The Paketo docs are pretty good if that’s the builder/buildpacks you’re using. If you have deeper questions there the Paketo slack is very active for support.

solution: 

issue: Ideally it would work, but it doesn't at the moment. In the jar case we can just decide not to add something to `BOOT-INF/lib`. In the war case, the war plugin's in control of what goes in `WEB-INF/lib` and we'd then need to figure out what shouldn't be there and remove it. https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/issues/15808 is tracking that fix.

solution: I have some questions regarding the use of `@Transactional` with coroutines:1) If I have code like:```kotlin@Transactionalfun myFun() {   // do DB stuff   runBlocking { suspendFun() }}// this would be in a different classsuspend fun suspendFun() {   // do more DB stuff}```Is it correct to assume that the `suspendFun()` can't see the transaction of `myFun()` because it's running in a different thread? Because I was trying to do this but was getting weird errors since the coroutine function couldn't see the uncommitted changes and so would lead to errors when trying to save an entity with a `@OneToOne` association that had been saved in `myFun()`.If so, is it somehow possible to pass the transaction context to the `runBlocking` call?2) If I instead lift the `runBlocking` to the top-level (controller) code, it seems to work OK. So my question then is: If I have```kotlin@Transactionalsuspend fun myFun() { ... }```will the transaction context be bound to the coroutine context? Some github issues seem to indicate that this would be the case.... 

issue: hello , why this dosn't work please```when(customerRepository.deleteById(customer.getId())).thenReturn(200);```Error : reason: no instance(s) of type variable(s) T exist so that void conforms to T 
solution: 

issue: The return type of `deleteById()`is void. And you're trying to make it return 200. Delete this line of code. If you call a void method on a mock, the method will just do nothing. You don't need to tell it to return something, since it can't return anything anyway. 
solution:

solution: 

issue: Passing the no-arg constructor resulted in the following compilation error  public State() {    } >Non-canonical record constructor must delegate to another constructor > Passing the no-arg constructor resulted in the following compilation errorAnyone? 
solution: 

issue: BeanPropertyRowMapper can't be used with records, since it consists in creating an instance of a Java Bean with its no-arg constructor, and then calling its setters to populate the bean. But records don't have a no-arg constructors, and are immutable and thus don't have setters. So, either use a traditional Java Bean, or use records, but then don't use BeanPropertyRowMapper. 
solution: 

issue: > tbh, I'm downgrading most of my projects to Java 8 because of Springs support so that's my main motivation, when will I be able to stop doing this :)What do you mean? I hope you're not downgrading because of Spring, we're marking sure that we're compatible with newer versions as soon as they're out. JDK8 is the baseline, not a "must have" https://start.spring.io/ defaults to JDK11, because this is the current LTS.

issue: I'm trying to implement using a ReadReplica-DataSource with a AbstractRoutingDataSource and TransactionSynchronizationManager#isCurrentTransactionReadOnly.But looking at AbstractPlatformTransactionManager, the threadlocal is always set after the call to determineCurrentLookupKey, so I always get false. solution: 

issue: This problem related to customizing buildpacks was reported in `2.5.0-M2`, and fixed in `2.5.0-M3` (released just last night). What version of Boot are you using? the location referred to in a binding must be a directory that contains a file named `type` and any other files that the binding should use. referring directly to the datadog.properties file won’t work. (forgot to link to the bug with custom buidpacks: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/issues/25378) 
solution: 

issue: @scottfrederick I've pulled down the latest version but still getting the same error. Do you want me to raise an issue with Spring Boot or should I use the verbose flag to get more information? 
solution: 

issue: As things stand, you'll have to make the jdbc transaction manager `@Primary` if that's the one that you want `SpringTransactionProvider` to use.  Arguably `JooqAutoConfiguration#transactionProvider` should be annotated with `@ConditionalOnMissingBean` so that you can provide your own. That would then give you more flexibility over how the right transaction manager is identified. Please open an issue if that's something you'd like us to take a look at doing. 
solution: 

issue: I can reproduce what you’re seeing. When the datadog binding is provided and properly formed, an image gets built. I can’t verify that datadog sets up the agent correctly, but I do get an image. When the datadog binding does not exist or is not properly formed (e.g. with a `type` file containing `DatadogTrace`), then I get the `No buildpack groups passed detection.`. I think this is because the datadog bp should be marked as “optional” in its metadata.
